Golden colour, small white head. Aroma is grain, barley, some slight US hops as well as some floral notes. Flavour is barley, slight floral and fruity notes along with some mild hayish notes. Easy to drink and quite balanced. Nothing mindblowing though.

Dark yellow colored with cloudy appearance. Little yellow head. Hopped aroma with nice toffee-chocolate coming up, grains also come up. Medium bodied. Flavor has same rich british hops dominating, lemon and some vegetables. Aftertaste turns to perfumy with mild toffee and some yeast.
Bottle To Pint Glass. Nice clear golden color with a bit of white head.  A touch of grain in the aroma and the taste is a bittery hopps.

At first sight it looks like a very pale lager with not a lot of flavor. In fact, I expected a lot darker. 
But then the flavor. Apricot, peach, lot of orange fruits with just the right amount of bitterness. Best Ive had in weeks.

clear yellow, smooth fine white head.
very nice flowery hoppy aroma, with a little fruity sort of bitter peachy note to it too. fantastic aroma. some orange too. just after pouring the aroma is unbelievably strong, full and appetizing.
flavor is sweet malty, and lots of pine , grapefruity bitter hops. alc is low and hidden, this is dangerously easy to drink. faint sugary sweetness too. damn this is good. lots of hops and flavor for a 5.7% abv beer. quenching .. way too bad this bottle is only like 35 cl or so.

Bottle at home. Pours a clear golden with a diminsihing white head. Sweet with hoppy aromas. Some dryness. Also some aromas of malts and caramel. Medium to light bodied. Soft carbonation. Dry finish with sugary hoppy aromas. Tastes a bit like a watered down Unearthly. Good.

Flaske: Flot orange øl med et lille skumhoved. Klar. Duft af humle, mango, appelsin og en smule citrus. Smagen er meget humlet igen med mango og en smule citron. Let bitter med en blød mundfylde. Rigtig god og lækker øl.

(Bottle at Pikkulintu) Poured pale golden and clear with small white head. Aroma contained hops and fresh grain. Palate was medium bodied with medium carbonation. Flavours were malts, grass, hops, grain, light sweetness and bitterness. Aftertaste was bitter and grainy.

Botella. Golden colour, medium nice steady white ehad. Pleasant hoppy sweet fruity aroma. Good mouthfeel indeed. Very pleasant and refreshing flavour:  some exotic fruits, good hoppiness, pleasant sweetness, bit of pine and a good fruity bit dry finish.

Bottle. Clear golden with a medium white head. Caramel, spicy hops, peach, mango and light barley aroma. The flavour is very fruity and piney with notes of peach and pineapple. Caramel, pine and barley in the finish. Very lovely brew.
Bottle. Floral/hop aroma. Light golden body- thin head.  Nice hop flavor with hints of malt. Dry finish with a bitter aftertaste
Bottled. Clear golden color, short white head. Aroma of grainy hops, some malt. Bit dryish grainy taste, quite bitter, slight sweet. Dry palate.
Bottle @ Hj Hansen, Odense. Pours clear golden with a small white head and lacings. Nose is freshly hopped. Citrus and pine. Medium bodied. Dry bitter and crisp flavor. Nice.

THOUGHTS: Not at all what I was expecting. It really didnt seem at all like an ESB. More like a British pale ale, but just slightly British at that. Not an awful beer, but it really missed the mark.
TECHNICAL: Bottle. Poured a slightly hazy, light gold with barely any head that left barely fair lacing. The aroma was light bread, caramel and biscuit; moderate to heavy pine, grapefruit and lemon hops; slight honey; and apricot. The initial flavor was sweet, slightly bitter and a little acidic; while the finish was acidic and bitter with a fairly long duration. It was nice but a little watery. There was light caramel malt, light bread and biscuit, lemony, piney hops, some yeast, metallic hops and perfumy hops. The light to medium body leaned more to the light side and was a little syrupy and then fairly dry with fizzy carbonation and a metallic and lightly dry finish.

Bottle, bought @ Ølbutikken, Cph.
Pours clear, dark golden with a fine, creamy, white head. Lovely hoppy aroma. Lots of grapefruit, light piney, peach and oranges. Medium carbonation, finde creamy mouthfeel. Light dryness. Flavour starts with a lots of fat maltiness, rather sweet, some caramel. Then a lots of grapefruity, resiny hops. Light oranges and lots of dryness in the rather long finish. Nice.
UPDATED: JAN 1, 2014 BOTTLE: clear light gold color, very mild hop nose. Taste is hop, citrus, a little malt that adds a bit of body as well. Easy drinking, but keeps some depth of flavor. Im a fan.

From a bottle on 11/01/09, pours a beautiful gold color.  No head that sticks around at all on the pour.  In the aroma it is as if you get a nice smell of some fresh hops along with almost a smell of fall in a  way.  On the palate you get hops, very balanced hops from the front through the finish.  Leaves the palate but who cares it goes down so damn easy.  Great beer to just throw back if you are in that type of mood.
Clear golden with a tiny white head. Hoppy aroma with lemons and malty notes. Sweet flavour with loads of hops, lemons and piney notes. Finished bitter.

Bottled. A golden beer with a lazing, bubbly off-white head. The aroma has strong notes hops, oranges, and malt. The flavor is sweet with strong notes of hops - American hops - Cascade, lending it notes of grapefruit and peaches, combined with notes of caramel and malt, leading to a dry and bitter finish. Nice.

12 fl oz bottle. Pours clear and golden orange with a small white head. Aroma is sweet and solid pinewood to grapefruity hoppy. Light sweetness, peachy, green apple and pinewood hops flavoured. Nice hoppy brew. Dry finish.

Bottle 35,5 cl. Courtesy of Ungstrup. Pours a clear golden with a rough white head. Extremely citrusy nose - very fresh. Medium body, a little sweet fruitiness and a dry and rather hoppy finish. Delicious, but nowhere near an ESB! 091109

12 oz. bottle from The Party Source.  Pours clear gold with a small white head that leaves some light lacing behind.  Hoppy aroma with citrus, grass, pine, and honey.  The flavor follows suit, hoppy, earthy, citrusy, and bitter.  Light bodied, well-balanced, and crisp.  Straightforward, excellent example of the style.

Clear golden pour with a thin white head. Aroma is citrus, grass, earth, mandarin, sap, evergreen resin. Its hard to get past the hop character- which is fantastic- but sweet caramel malt is just on the other side. Flavor is sweet honey and caramel malt with a robust hop character that rears its resinous head with orange and spruce. Palate is full for the style, but remains delicately effervescent and smackingly hoppy. Caressing and delicious- at the apex of its style.

Clear gold pour, minimal head. Aroma holds tons of tangerine and grapefruit, honey, tree sap, pine resin, and tons of other hop characteristics. Tough to get past the hops to the malt; perhaps a bit of caramel and other sweet malt. Flavor is marked by a combination of American and English hops; aroma really reminded me of a big IPA, but the flavor betrays its English roots. Excellent bitterness, flavors are toned down from the aroma, but still very tasty; lots of evergreen and citrus still. Palate is light, smooth, and very drinkable; would love to put down a 6 pack of this stuff. Really nice brew, one of my favorite ESBs in recent memory.

Bottle at På Besök, Malmö.
Clear golden coloured with a small white head.
Fruity aroma of hops, caramel and pine needles with notes of grass.
Fruity flavour of hops, caramel and pine needles with notes of grass.
Dry hoppy finish.

Light yellow with finger width white head.  Floral and citrus aroma with some fruity notes.  Light body with a slightly bitter hop flavor.  Really light finish.  Very pleasant and enjoyable but not very complex.

12oz Bottle  Gravity Beer Market  Olympia, WA
Aroma: Nice malt and good hops aroma.  
Appearance: Orange Amber in color, Clear with a light head.  
Flavor: Nice malt with great spice backing.  This was a very limited ESB.   
Palate:  Dry with a smooth finish.  
Overall: This was a good beer not quite the ESB you usually get the flavors where to rich and strong.  But spices in the brew.

Bottled. Golden coloured. Unclear. Dense off white head. Aroma of fruits, sweetness, flowers and light pine. Flavour is flowery, fruity, piney and has some sweetness and caramel. medium to full bodied. Ends on a sweet bitterness, which lingers for quite a while. Nice one.
Cereal grainy nose with grassy hop presence.  Solid bread malt body, dry with some caramel notes.  Crisp and floral hop character. Slightly resinous with sharp pine.

Pours a remarkably clear yellow with no head. Aroma is very faint - dominated by earthy hops. Taste is bread, lemon, and a solid grapefruit-like bitter finish. Drinkable and enjoyable. Would be a good thirst-quencher in the summer too.

Pours a clear gold with a small white head that collapses to a thin skin of bubbles. The aroma...wow! The nose is a beautiful blend of "candied" citric and lightly resinous hops over pale/caramel malt. Light to medium-bodied and soft with a nice, moderate, tongue-squeezing bitterness that lingers beyond the swallow. Sweet, lightly bready and caramel malt flavors with solid citric hops in support; it finishes with a nice bitterness. This beer was a nice surprise despite the fact that beastiefan2k had told me it was his favorite ST beer. I shouldve known it had to be good given hes generally such a pussy when it comes to hoppy beers. ;)

Bottle at home - shared with Mette. Clear golden - white head. Fresh hoppy, light candy, sweetness, fresh grass, bisquit, knækbrød (swedish flatbread), medium malty, soapy, nice bitterness, lovely hop aroma. Very high drinkalility.

Clear yellow, soggy white head.  Excellent hoppy aroma, very bright and dynamic.  yes.  dynamic.  Very WC in character, lacks malt balance, but as a standalone beer I really enjoy the strong hop character.  Very light bodied and almost weak.  Id drink 4 before I knew it.

12oz bottle from dmac. Pours clear, straw yellow with a thin white head and good lace. Smells crisp and citrusy hoppy, slightly sweet with slight cereal malt. Tastes hoppy and nice. Clean and citrusy and nice and crisp. Slightly nutty with some cereal malts. Thin body, good carbonation.

Crystal clear gold with a nice white head.
 Herbal and citrus hops with some lemon and grapefruit. Not the hop bomb aroma I was expecting but still hoppy and nice.
Crisp and very refreshing. Light citrus and fruit with minimal but well done malt notes. Some grapefruit and lemon and maybe a hint of orange.  Perfectly carbonated body. Crisp feel.
This would be marvolous on a warm afternoon but works just as well on a cool fall evening.  Could easily do 4 or so pints because it doesnt kill your tongue.  Lovely.  (Draught at Thrash Zone, Yokohama)

Hazy straw color with a small white head. Fresh hop aroma with some nice citrus notes. Has a flavor mostly dominated by hops, but does have a slight malty sweetness that balanced things nicely. Quite refreshing, but overall nothing real special.

Dark straw to golden in color with a white head that shows some lacing from its pillow top head. Notes of citrus and grapefruit from the nose with a slight touch of wood. Light bodied and balanced with a slight hop character creeping up on finish.
Wonderfully floral, spicy hop bite, but refreshing.    Very well done Oktoberfest-type ale,

Light orange with a light head and plenty of clingyness.  Aromas of herbal, floral and citrus hops.  Tastes fresh, grassy, toasted malts with an ending of bitter herbs and grapefruit.  Goes very well with pumpkin ravioli.
Clear golden color with a fleeting white head. Grassy hop and pine aromas. Medium body. Lightly bitter sweet flavors of grass, spicy, grapefruit hops, and pale bready malts.
user_location: Same Trailer, Different Park, Louisiana, USA

text: Crisp and refreshing. Surprised that I liked this. Piney scent, golden clear look, white head. The finish is dry but a tad odd....leaves a bad aftertaste???

Golden pour with hardly any white head very citrusy floral hop aroma not carbonated much taste of malt caramel and then straight citrus hop and a slight bitter finish very smooth transition from malt to hop and a great brew.  Not deep ruby in color which is weird.  Very drinkable!
UPDATED: DEC 30, 2009 Pale orange color and a big hoppy aroma. Almost herbal in that sense, sort of Marijuana-like even. Really nicely balanced taste pattern that is mostly bitter.

12oz bottle.  Clear golden color with not much head.  What a great smelling nose for an ESB.  Cracker like malt with a delicious blast of peach hop resin.  Thin body and carbonation is lacking...a bit on the flat side.  Really kind of watery with a dusty dry bittering up front and then some sweet maltiness mid palate finishing up with some weird metallic bitterness.  This has just a odd finish and rather unpleasant.  I am trying, but I dont think I will be finishing this one.

12oz. bottle.  Massively hoppy aroma, fresh, leafy, piney, floral and citric, with a very light degree of malt sweetness present.  Clear medium golden color with a very fine, slight head.  Flavor profile is similarly hop-focused, with a large amount of American hop character throughout, bringing pine, spice, grapefruit and lemon rind, very bright and citrusy, the malts lightly sweet with very faint caramel and toast, and a generous amount of bitterness hitting up front, fading towards the finish.  Crisp, lightly carbonated and resinous on the palate, body is medium.  The six-pack holder proclaims "quadrupulus humulus lupulus", which is pretty accurate.

12 oz. bottle. Fresh green hops are right upfront as I pour. Golden ale colorall right, English bitter colorunder a chunky big head. Now, I got this in July (loose bottle rack at Binnys), so this must actually be LAST YEARs Harvest Ale. Thats why I miss the vegetal green hop of a fresher bottle. Still, theres a good hop burn here youd normally expect from a northwestern American hop bomb. Still brings in notes of citrus peel and myrtle Seems fine for its age otherwise, malts are tasty and stay back while hops do their thing. Loose bottle was 99¢.

Just so dam drinkable.  Hazy yellow color from tap.  The aroma does not give off the great taste.  Perfect combination of hops and malt give it a grapefuit type bitterness with just a bit of that fresh from the fields buzz.

Bottle.  This is one of the better ESBs that I have had.  Golden pour.  Medium head.  Floral and herbal hops on the nose to go along with apricot.  Flavor is much the same. Juicy hops and malt combine to make a really nice beer.  Good job ST.

Enjoyed from a 12oz bottle in a pub glass.  The beer pours a light golden color, as opposed to the "deep ruby" that was advertised on the bottle.  This isnt the only odd item about this beer.  The nose is very hoppy, resembling an IPA more than an ESB, and pretty much totally outside of the style.  I am all for pushing style limits and being experimental, but this beer resembles a strong and too-hoppy American Pale Ale more than an English pale ale.  The misrepresentation transfers to the palate, as the beer is bracingly bitter, far too much for what is supposed to be a subtle and restrained style.  Additionally, this example doesnt contain nearly the malt character that is needed for the style.  Instead, there is a nice hop flavor in place of malt.  The presence of some crystal malt would definitely serve to improve the beer though.  Overall, this is a good beer, but it is outside of the style to a point that is a detriment.

Grapefruit dominates a big hoppy aroma, with some what smell like traditional english malts... Huge grapefruit hoppy flavor with subtle maltiness backing nicely, flavorful without being over the top... top notch beer...

Pours a clear light amber with a little yellowy head. Wasnt expecting this to be have the hoppy nose or flavor I got from it, so it was a bit of a curve ball but still very nice. Not too hoppy to be considered an IPA, very drinkable, and very enjoyable. Malts are present in small amounts. Nice mouthfeel. Good beer from a good brewery.

12 oz bottle from EZ Liquors. Poured a clear thinner looking orange body sitting underneath a foamy bright white head. Aroma was fresh grass, citrus hops and sweet biscuit. Medium bodied with a good dose of carbonation and a very bitter finish. Flavor was lots of citrus, slightly sweet malts, a touch of orange marmelade. Very nice beer from Southern Tier but an ESB?? Not so sure about that.

Golden yellow with next to no head.  Aroma of mild hops, sweet malt, citrus and mild sticky fruit.  Taste of mild grassy and citrus hops, light fruit and grains with some light bitterness on the back end.

12 oz bottle. Pours a light golden orange with a small white froth. Aroma is a nice blend of citric fruitiness and a rich caramel malt. Nicely fresh hops with some tangerine and a bit of toastiness. Flavor is also nice and fresh hops, citric and refreshing. Becomes much sweeter towards the finish resulting in a balanced very hoppy bitter. Medium creamy body. Very tasty for a cold fall day, which it is now.

Sampled from a 12 oz brown bottle this beer poured a dark golden color with a small white head. The aroma was dryish fruity hops with a touch of nut. The flavor was tart, bitter and dryish with a crisp floral and fruity hop presence. The finish was medium length bitter fruity hops. The body was a bit thin. Ok.
From a bottle poured a hazy orangish color with a fair amount of head.  Malty sweet flavor with a quick finish.

UPDATED: OCT 11, 2009 Boy was this one helluva surprise. I saw the name Harvest Ale and right away thought of semi malty caramel beers with a bite.
Oktoberfest is one of my least favorite styles. Now knowing S.T I figured they added some hops to balance it out. What I got was one of the best IPA style beers I have had to date.
 Like someone mentioned earlier the color looks like typical macro beer. That is where it ends. Huge billowing head. Killer clinging lacing. Citrus hops. Little bit of pine. Full bodied mouth feel and $9 a six. You NEED this.

Bottle.  Pours a slightly hazy light golden color with a two finger white head.  Heavy citrus aroma with some earthy tones.  Moderate hoppy initial flavor mellows out with a smooth, citrusy finish.  Sticky texture with good carbonation.  Well worth a try if your a fan of Fall seasonals.

Pours gold into a shaker. Bright white head quickly recedes to hug rim leaving spotted spider lacing.  Grapefruit and resin aromas.  Fresh summer pit fruits upfront with a lasting sweet grapefruit finish.

Appearance:  Pours a deep yellow gold with a 1/8 inch of dense white foam. You can see a good amount of rising bubbles in the body as you hold it up to the light.

Aroma:  Slight amounts of citrus, pear, bread notes mixed with some sweetness.

Taste:  Light amounts of lemon and bready dry malt. Finishes with a decent amount of clean bitter Euro hops.

Mouthfeel: Medium bodied and creamy.

Overall:  A nice showcase of European hops.  I cant say this beer blew my mind, but its solid to above average in my book.

UPDATED: SEP 16, 2009 aroma of huge hops: pine, lemon, soap, and near candy sweetness all fleeting through and mixing at once. appearance is straw yellow and quite translucent with nice carb but film head. flavor is strong grapefruit hop note usually only found in an IIPA but without the alcoholic burn or extreme bitterness associated with that style. huge toasty malt comes through late.  its easy to be distracted with the fruity hops but the malt character and the balance it lends is what makes this a superstar.  palate is wet but enjoyable.  one of few flagship (non-22oz) ST beers that is worth its while, disappointed in myself for passing on this last year.

Bottle compliments of Ben, thank man! Pours a clear golden, yellow and looks a whole lot more like a light macro than I would like it to. Nose has some good fresh citrus. Mouth is a juicy and dry hop flavor, nice and refreshing yet very dry and bitter. Similar to Founders Harvest in taste, just a little watery in comparison. Not bad on a warm fall afternoon to Kick off Colts season.

Bruegala 2009 sampling - The typical representation for the old saying "Dont judge a book by its cover". Appearance was a bright clear bright yellow, small thin filmy white head with almost no carbonation. If based on looks alone, this beer fails. Aroma is quite surprising with a very light grainy malt note, average amount of pin, grapefruit and resiney hops notes and a heavy peach aroma. Flavor has a very strong peach sweetness with a modest pine and grapefruit hops notes with a good hops bitter bite. Body is moderate with a light oily note and an almost flat feeling but it carries the flavor fantastically. Overall a bit on the thin side (probably due to under carbonation) but it really does stand out as a great brew with a lot complexity in the aroma and flavors.

This beer is GOOD.  Nice hoppy floral aroma and slick on the mouth.  A slim malt backbone IMO, but the hops are what makes this beer.  Seems like theres a few different types here - definitely some cascade in there.   Awesome American-style ESB (if that makes sense).
12 ounce bottle. Nice hop aroma. Very nice hops taste in the foretaste. The aftertaste is slightly bitter with a smooth finish. Very solid beer would buy again
user_location: The World of Beer, Texas, USA

text: Yummmmmm-ooooooo!!! Wow, great beer! Poured with a big, foamy, frothy, thick, white head and good lace. Color is 18 k yellow gold. Aroma is very fresh, citrus hop. Flavor is super fresh hop but not so citrus, more earthy & chewy hop, some malt, and bread. Body is good, a little soft. Carbonation is good. Finish is excellent. Satisfying yet leaves me with a yearning for more, and more, and....
YUM.  Thought this was going to be an Oktoberfest, but its actually a tight bitter.  Crisply hopped and delicious... wish we got this in NC.

Clear, bright yellow/gold appearance with a small, off white head and good lacing.  Spicy hop aroma with some citrus underneath.  Hops turn more floral and herbal in the taste, accompanied by some cracker-like malts.  Aftertaste is pleasantly bitter.  First impression, erroneously, was that the palate was a bit too thin; but there is a good firm body ir you give it a chance.  "Harvest" = "Octoberfest"?  Sounds reasonable, but not here.  Think more bitter hoppiness and less sweet maltiness.  A new favorite for this style.

POurs yellow with a thin white head. Nose is crisp toasty grain, subtle and perfectly balanced citrus hops, fruity english yeast. Flavor is a refreshing citrus bitterness perfectly balanced by sweet toasty caramel malt. This would be my session beer if I could get it regularly. ESB is a very under appreciated style, but when executed well, like this beer, its a gem!
Amber pour with offwhite head.  Aroma is of fruity hops and a bit of pine.  Malts are earthy.  Flavor is mild hop bitterness and some nice robust malt to ballance.  Very drinkable. Pretty tastey

Bottle.  Pours a clear pale amber with a medium to large white head.  Citrus hops with a little pine, a bit of mango, and a touch of grain behind it.  Medium body, light bitterness up front with a little sweetness behind it. Finishes up with a slow grapefruit bitterness.  Tasty.

Bottle. Light amber color with snowy lace. Big citrus nose-fragrant and balanced, lots of pine. Earthy amber malt flavor, light, with hgue citrus: grapefruit and pine. A bit of caramel too. Big on hops, though well balanced, with great aromas and good bitterness. Nice stuff!

Bottle. Aroma is like a fresh picked hop cone. Pours a golden yello with a pretty small head. Taste is mostly hops, light malt presence. Very smooth and drinkable. I love the smell of this one. I should have been drinking this while picking the hops.

12 oz bottle experienced on a camping trip with Adrian910ss.  Pours a clear golden orange colour with a white head.  Aroma of hops, citrus, lemon, grass. Flavor is the same as the aroma. A bit of a watery palate.

Bottle at Dayton Ale Fest.  Pours a light orange with this white head.  Aroma is very "wet hop"with barley any malt pressence there at all.  Notes of fresh pine, grass, citrus, and grapefruit stand out.  On the palate, it is thin and watery.  The flavor is really watered down.  It brings out a bit of a caramel malt backbone, but not much.  It finishes rather refreshing.  I was a little disappointed of in this beer.  The aroma was awesome, but on the palate it was pretty weak.

Phenomenal "wet hop" aroma. Pine sap and spruce. Grassy with a sweet citrus (orange/grapefruit). Fresh cat piss! Bready rye-like and caramel malts. The appearance is not incredible. Healthy white head, though short-lived. Clear golden yellow color. Transparent. The flavor is a bready, sweet and roasted caramel malt backbone. Bitter piney hops come afterward. Beautifully balanced. Hops run the gamut from estery to bitter oak. Feels gritty but not too thick. A nice bite at the swallow. Its a terrifically balanced, sweet and bitter brew. A helluva good autumn beer.

Bottle . A bright golden orange pour with a lasting foamy white head , lost of lacing left , medium carbonation . Aroma of citrus zest and light floral notes, with a hint of pine . Flavor of light toasted caramel malt , orange and citrus , with some piny resin , nice level of bitterness . Medium body with a clean mouthfeel . Nice hoppy finish . Very good and sessionable . A very good brew from Southern Tier .

Pours clear golden with a quickly disappearing light white head/  The aroma has dank hops, citrus, pine and minimal hops that seem to be somewhere between and ESB and APA.  This has a light crisp body with lightly sharp carbonation.  The flavor begins with the nice hoppiness with lots of funkiness to the hops, dry malt and leans a bit towards the ESB malt, but the APA notes are still noticeable.  The finish is very dry and hoppy.  I like this one quite a bit.
Big citrus hop aroma.  Flavor is mostly grapefruit with a touch of orange peel. Tangy.
Great session ale thats hoppy, bitter skunky hoppy with a skunky funky taste of light pumpkin spice and subdued aged hops. Fruity a bit, but perfectly bitter as well. Great great beer.
Herbal, rather than fruity, aroma and taste. Gold/red color, and filtered to be completely clear. I like "floaties" in my brews!

Pours a crisp golden collor with a thin white head. Aroma is straight out citrus, grapefruit, tangerine, a little lemon.  Flavor is predominantly grapefruit with a sweet little malt backbone.  This is a perfect beer for a hot summer night. really nice.

12 oz. bottle at Lunar Brewing Co., Villa Park, IL. Poured to a Czech-pils glass, a medium gold color with an off white, modest, foamy head and some streaky lacing. The aroma was subtle tangerine, other citrus, and smooth malt. The flavor added an initial low but consistent bitterness, and some light candy sweetness. Medium to light bodied with a pleasant dryness to the finish. Refreshing and sessionable.
Sampled at Blacklick Wine and Spirits weekly tasting.  A nice golden pour with sweet hoppy notes.Flavor was citrusy sweet with some bitterness on the backend.

Sampled at the imports tasting at Blacklick Wine & Spirits on 8/13/09.  Clear gold/orange pour with a thin white head.  Citrusy and spicy hops in the aroma with not a lot of malt.  Earthy and spicy hops with a touch of citrus and once again very little malt balance.  Tastes more like an unforgiving IPA than an ESB, but hell, it tastes good.
Sampled at tasting at Blacklick Wine and Spirits. Pour was nice amber color. Strong aroma of sweet grass. Flavor was very grapefruity and orange peel. Hoppy finish

Nice clear, golden yellow color with a decent stark-white head. Flowery hop aromas and then a floral taste as well. Some maltiness in the back, bitterness, nice beer. I wouldnt have suspected this is an ESB. Thanks to vwcraig for including this on a recent trade.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 01-26-2008 05:46:05
Bottle shared by andrew... Sweet candy sugar nose. Light orange-ish in color, ok head. Dry taste....sweet malts. Light in texture. Really easy to drink. Good beer for a session.

What a surprise this beer was.  Most of the "exceptional" Southern Tier ales are only available in 22oz. bottles.  Most of their 12 oz. bottles are good beers but not exceptional.  Harvest Ale is exceptional.  A great hoppy earthy flavor.  Not much of a lasting head, but a great smooth finish.  Its a shame its seasonal.
Clear Gold color.  WHite head quickly disappeared.  Citrus and Pine aroma.  Grassy start then citrus and pine flavors follow.  Smooth Finish.  Thin watery feel in mouth.  This is a nice hoppy beer.

12 fl oz bottle into a pint glass delivered a creamy head.  While not a fan of hoppy ale this ESB delivers.  I believe the added fresh malted barley smoothes the tartness from the hops.  A apricot flavor is faintly there and this beer is excellent.
UPDATED: APR 11, 2010 Had on tap at Valhalla in NYC.  A nice ale from southern tier.  Has a good hop and spice flavor.  Another awesome randition from southern tier

Bottle on 10/27/2008. Clear golden body with a large frothy off-white head. Toasty and floral hoppy aroma with some cheerios. More toasty cheerios flavor, with floral hops shining through in the background. Medium light body with moderately high carbonation.

Bottle from dkachur. Thanks. Pleasant fruity aroma of light citrus oranges, a touch of sweet juiciness. Pours light gold with a thin soapy head. Nice fruity hops upfront with a moderately light malty mid palate. Nice juicy fruit finish. Vibrant carbonation light body quenching hops. Really sessionable and balanced.

12oz bottle from a recent trade or another kind soul....pours a semi-transparent apricot orange with a thin soapy white head..... aroma of citrusy/pineapple hops ..... flavors were citrusy upfront, a sweeter malty middle and finished with a dry hop bitterness.  moderate carbonation level.  not too bad but lacking some flavor in making this more memorable.
Pours an orange-tan color with a white head.  Aroma of hops and citrus.  Flavor of citrus with a slight bitter finish.  Crisp and refreshing.

12 oz. bottle picked up from the infamous Binny’s Singles Rack (Orland Park, IL). Straw / light gold pour slightly hazed with a moderate white head and well carbonated body. Aromas are heaven: Lemony and Orange hop citrus notes, some light candy gumballness, and mango. Yum. Taste is a bit more muted, light doughy malt is balanced over so by citrusy hops with a touch of gumball sweetness. Not so much a harvest ale as a summer sessioner. Very nice. Finishes with a prominent bitterness that lets you know it isn’t a summer brew, but lighter on malt. A different take on a harvest ale that is very sessionable, flavorful.

Pours a somewhat hazy orange color with an off white head. Aroma was sweet malty character with hints of hops im not acustom to.  Flavor was really smooth nice maltiness but not too sweet, and a nice biting hop finish. This would be an excellent session beer.

Gold pour and decent head.  The label is not so impressive.  It has a fine floral hop aroma with hints of honey and tropical fruit.  I expected this to be an Oktoberfest type of brew, but instead it tastes more like a crisp pale ale (I see that Ratebeer is calling it a premium bitter).  It is light on the malt, well-hopped, and mildly astringent.  The aftertaste is slightly bitter.  Here is a well-crafted, flavorful dry ale.

This one took me by surprise. I was expecting an Oktober fest brew of sorts. This one, however was packed full of delicious hops, mostly of the citrus variety. The harvest element of this brew comes through in a spicy malt character that follows the hop bitterness. Not an overly complex brew, which is not always a bad thing. Overall a great harvest brew that I will definitely get again.

Reviewed on: 10-07-2007
Bottle. Aroma of grassy, floral, and lightly citrusy hops. Juicy, slightly biscuity maltiness in the mouth with those grassy/floral hops still abundant. Very drinkable and tasty.

12 oz bottle.  Pours a orange-amber color with a white head.  Aroma is floral hops with orange.  Flavor is a nice mellow malt flavor with a moderate amount of hop kick to it.  Finishes pretty crisp without any offensive aftertaste.

Bottle. Pours a dark yellow-gold, a bit hazy, with a very thing off-white head that leaves beautiful lacing. Nose is orange blossoms and a bit of resin, with some biscuity malt coming through also. Taste begins with a bit of orangey citrus and sweet biscuity malt on the font of the tongue, with some spiciness coming through from the hops also. With the swallow, a light bitterness from the hops sits on the palate, especially the back of the tongue, and the biscuity malt sweetness swells again before giving way to the spicy hops. Bigger flavor, light on the palate. Paradoxical kind of beer. Fantastic sessionability, light, but delicious.

12oz bottle. Pours clear orange with nice white head. Aroma floral hops with orange, light fruits and other citrus aromas. Flavor is hoppy with orange and sweet malt and light spices. Finishes bitter and is a bit syrupy on palate. Very good fall session beer. Nicely done ST.
Crisp and refreshing beer. Dont usually buy 6 packs, but I think I could down six of these like nothing. Crsip hoppy palate. Clean finish. Light bitter back end.
Great fall beer. chalky in texture. Seems like more hops than alot of the compitiition.I could put down a few of these.

UPDATED: NOV 18, 2008 Bottle. Pours a very light orange with a foamy white head. Color is a little weak. Aroma of citrus and grassy hops. Flavor of citrus hops initial with a light sweet fruity finish and subtle hoppy finish. Very nice, very refreshing, very drinkable. Excellent!
12 oz. bottle at Flat Rock Saloon.  Poured hazy gold with poor carbonation.  Starts sweet with spicy hop finish.

Bottle.  Pours a pale orange body with a light white head.  Sweet malt backbone dominated by hop resins and a winy grassy spicy hop character.  Mouth tingling hop spiciness, then copper hop leaf.  A bit earthy and dry.  No etoh to notice, malt body stays light.

Style and Glass: ESB; English pint
ABV, Volume & Calories: 5.7 % in 12 fl oz. estimated at 150 C
Purchased at: Super Saver, Pennington, NJ for $2.00

Aroma: nice, wheat, hay, hops, corn, sugar. 8 out of 10.

Visuals: good design, golden, clear, long lasting white head, sticky lace. 5 out of 5.

Taste: expertly balanced, medium malt, medium hops, medium strength, well crafted. 10 out of 10.

Palate: high quality, chalky texture, long medium bitter finish. 5 out of 5.

Overall: A beautiful example of what an everyday or session brew should be, an absolute repeat, not a favorite, but its not my favorite style either, high value, high craft. This is what Budweiser Ale should strive hard to be. 20 out of 20.

Presentation: It was poured from a brown 12oz bottle into a pint glass

Appearance: It has a bright golden color with a slight chill haze and a small creamy white head. It fades to just a very thin covering that still makes some nice lace on the glass.

Smell: The aroma has a hop filled nose with piney/citrus notes and a hint of caramel and toasted grain.

Taste/Mouth feel: Its flavor has a good malty backbone with light toasted notes as well as a mild almost fruity sweetness. This is balanced by good bitterness from the hops which add some piney/citrus notes. In the finish I picked up more of a herbal tea like hop flavor that slowly fades off the tongue. It has a solid medium body with good carbonation and a slightly slick texture.

Notes: I wasn’t expecting a ESB for a harvest beer but it was very enjoyable.

12 ounce bottle in pint glass. Golden orange with flat white head and some lace.  Hoppy fresh citrus orange aroma.  Mild toasted honey orange fresh fruity sweetness with strong hop bitterness and nice fresh hop flavor.  Nice assertive finish.  A little light on the body, medium carbo.  Refreshing and assertive.  Lots of good sweet fruity and hoppy flavors mixed together.  Nice.
Pours yellow/gold with a nice white head.  Smells of tea, some rosey hints, pepper.  Tastes dry and rosey with some nice spicy hints on the finish.

hazy yellow color, slight white head, some lacing.  aroma of musty grass.  flavor of bitter malt and grass.  full bodied, long lasting bitter finish.  an interesting, if not complex, brew with a mild bitterness that lingers.  not sure what this means, but my notes say "goes good with sport peppers".
Smells wonderfully of sour floral hops. Tastes hoppier than your average harvest ale with a nice well-balanced malt back to it. One of the best of this style I’ve had

12oz bottle from the Big E grocery store.  This fall beer is light, hoppy, and spicy.  It tastes like a light bodied IPA with a little bit of British hops in the finish.  I can’t believe that this is an ESB.  The hops are harsh and acidic like a west coast double, but the body of the beer is very light.  This was very different and enjoyable.
Sweet grain and fresh hop aroma.  The flavor is fairly dry with some malt sweetness on the finish.  This beer’s flavor somehow reminds me of crunchy dry autumn leaves.

Somewhat pallid pour...light golden and thin-looking, but the nose has a fair touch of grassy hop bite to it.  The flavors are big bright grassy hoppiness and citrusy finish layered on top of the biscuit and bready caramel maltiness underneath.  Very nice take on the premium bitter style and preminently repeatable!

Well, it looks basic enough, glassy yellow hue with a thin head.  Aroma is a great balance of nutty malt, (I love nutty malt aroma) and a light hop citrus.  Did I mention that I love nutty malt characters?  ’Cuz I do, and this mingles with well with a mild hop build.  Not the most memorable ESB, but a damn fine example.  And kudos to Southern Tier for brewing a harvest ale that has nothing to to do with spices or pumpkins.

Bottle.  Pours a slightly orange-ish gold with a medium sized, sudsy head (that dies back fairly quickly.)  Aromas are fairly crisp... pine and citrus, but they are kind of subdued.  While those hops dominate the nose and would make you think you were headed down the IPA path, flavor is more consistent with an English ESB...  kind of a sweet honey and bread malt body with a bitter hops to hold it in check... it stays nice and crisp throughout and is pleasant enough.
user_location: The Wet Side of a Dry Town, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Draught @ Cole’s. Clear golden, leaves some lacing. Lovely pine hopped-up aroma. Medium carbonation. Floral, pine and citrus all mortared and pestled together into a very nice brew!!

Poured a dark golden color with a medium sized, off white head that left light lacing on the glass.  Aroma of floral hops, pine, citrus, toast, and toffee.  Taste of citrus fruits, toffee, yeast, toasted malts, a bit of caramel, and a moderately bitter finish.

Thanks to egajdzis.  12 oz bottle.  Pours a translucent golden copper with a medium off white head that left spotty lacing.  Aroma of a handful of fresh hops, floral, orange, nice citrus mix, bready and caramel.  Flavor of citrus zest, floral, pine, lightly bitter, bready malt, grains and some caramel.
12oz bottle. Pours a crystal clear, deep golden color with a 2 finger off white head.  Nose of citrus hops and pine.  Finish was hoppy with some malt and good bitterness.

Pours a clear, light honey gold with a minimal white head. Incredible aroma of sweet honey and an abundance of citrus and pine scented hops. Delicious taste, rivals some top IPA’s in my opinion. Very smooth sweet honey and orange flavors at the start that fade amazingly into a great bitter but controlled hop finish. If anything it’s a little too herbal tasting as it lingers, but still exceptional.
12 oz bottle-pours a thin off white head and gold color.  Aroma is lemon-citrus/pine hops, secondary medium malt.  Taste is soapy, dry grapefruit rinds, tannins/aspirin, husky.

Poured from a 12oz bottle and served in an English pint glass.  This beer poured a clear, light amber with a thin head of off-white foam that showed some decent retention.  Solid lacing covered the entire glass.  The aroma was made up of bright citrus and apricot, along with a light underlying note of caramel.  Smells really fresh, but not overpowering.  The flavor was moderately bitter, featuring mild grapefruit, apricot, caramel, and also some lightly toasted bread.  A hint of mildly astringent orange peel started to creep in towards the end of the glass.  The mouthfeel was medium-bodied and lightly carbonated.  Slightly sticky.  Overall, this was a really nice beer.  Quite tasty and sessionable.

Really good.  Nice hop aroma/flavor.  Bitterness is not overpowering.  There is a solid resinous flavor, without a lingering bitterness on the palate.  Well balanced, clean, crisp, a very well done harvest ale.

UPDATED: OCT 4, 2011 Bottle from 3 Sons and Great Bitter, but not ruby in color.  Golden with great head and lacing.  Really big hops all the way through with exceptionally clean finnish.  Much Like Matt and Finns
10/2011 i dont know what they did and totally unlike Southern Tier, this taste like a second squezzing, thin and weak/

Picked up at the United Liquors in Frankfort, IL:  This pours a clear yellow/gold body with a frothy white head that performs heavy lacework.  It has a solid aroma of floral and citrus zest hops smells over a lightly sweet grainy malt.  The bitterness from the hops is quite pronounced in the flavor, overshadowing the sweetness from the grains.  Dry bitter finish.  Nice.
Sweet malt aroma with light grain. Cloudy dark yellow color with a small white head. Fruity malt beginning with a mild amount of hops in the middle and finish. Somewhat sticky palate.

Bottle: Pours a nice golden with good clarity and a strong/creamy white head. The aroma is a nice mix of American & British hop varieties- crispy citrus cascade bouquet and some crackery dried malt in the back. Has a nice creamy texture. The flavor has an interesting malt character offering cracker and peanut skins. Crisp American hops come through with a spicy citrus notes and zest. The finish leans toward the British hop varieties with a mild herbal note into the solid bitter ending. Very nice stuff.
Really a nice harvest ale.  Straw gold in the glass with a good sized head.  Plenty of hops and a clean finish.  Fresh-tasting and light bodied.

The pour is rich golden yellow, with a thin sudsy white head.  The aroma is strong hops and some citrus.   The Hop flavor is stronger than the aroma leads you to believe, But the malt balances wuite well.  body is fuller than most esbs.  Flavor lingers with a touch slow on the finish.  Pretty good beer.

UPDATED: SEP 10, 2010 Bottle. Pours a clear bright amber with a frothy white head and laceing that sticks to the sides of the glass as you drink.  Crisp hoppy nose with hints of pine and citrus. Flavor is slightly bitter but fairly balanced.  Its very light on the tongue with a bit of a watery wet hops finish.  Mouth is left feeling damp but thirsty.  This was a decent beer but not one that deserves to be in the 90th percentile [currently 91].  The aroma and appearance are not particularly noteworthy and the flavor is comparable to a slightly hoppier [and lighter] version of Sam Adams [decent - not great]. The aftertaste is a little soapy, which was disheartening.  Id give this a chance if I ever saw it on tap but there are way too many good beers out there for me to go out of my way to find this again.

12 oz. bottle from Wine Warehouse in Charlottesville. Golden color with a medium head. Very big hops in the aroma, resin and pine, with a caramel backbone. Spicy and resiny hop taste with caramel in the background. Sticky, full bodied. Very nice. It’s a hop bomb bitter... I like!

Bottle. Pours clear gold with a white head. Wonderful fresh hoppy aroma, with floral, citric and peachy notes. The body is smooth and the flavor is very well balanced, with more floral hops and peach. Very nice.
nice golden color, with big fluffy white head, lots of lacing on glass. lots of hop smell and grain some malt, lots of bitter and hop taste, pretty nice beer

Pours golden with a white head. Tons of hops on the aroma, mostly pine, and a touch of malt.  Lots more hops on the flavor, bitter but under control, malt is good for balance. Not my favorite style but still a solid beer.
Pours a clear yellow gold with a medium white head.  Aroma of bitter piney hops with a floral tone touch.  Taste is bitter hoppy with hints of light pine and grapefruit.

Pours a very clear light copper color with a small white head. Aroma is medium sweet, light grapefruit and malty. Flavor is grapefruit, light caramel, light spice and bready. Medium dry finish. Light-medium body, light sticky texture.

Say, this is good.  Wasn’t sure what to expect; thought it might be an Oktoberfest style.  Instead lovely fresh hops on the nose, and nice and toasty malt. Slightly nutty flavor of toasted pumpkin seeds.  Good malt balance.  Really tasty.

ST, expecting an over the top experience. Lid pop yeilds hop candy pine aroma. Looks ubiquitous pale yellow but is sparkling nicely. Rude hop taste bud bitter mowing  palate. Premium bitter?  More like an IPA.  Soapy oily with lots of biting personality. Lingering bitter nearly terrible slippery mouth coating medicinal finish. Most likely would not purchase again. Burping volatile hoppy gasses. Quite difficult one time 12 oz bottle.
user_location: Beaver Valley, Beaver County, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Bottle: pours a nice clear golden amber color with a frothy white head, nice fresh hoppy aroma, a little citrus, taste is hoppy with a nice bitter finish - though not overpowering bitterness, I could drink a lot of this stuff.  Southern Tier always seems to do the hoppy beers real well and this one is no exception.

Bottle.  Pours a very light copper, yellowish color- certainly not the "deep ruby" noted in the description.  Decent head. Nose is sharp and crisp, lots of light floral and some citrus notes. Flavor is mostly hops- heavy on the bitterness, but not at all abrasive. Heavy on the grapefruit and lemon, c-hop citric flavors.  Good, though no especially exciting.

I love this beer! Pours a light clear orange/amber with lots of tiny bubbles and a medium thick white creamy froth.   Fantastic fresh citrus hop aroma with lesser notes of pine, grapefruit and sugary malt.  First taste is very earthy and extremely bitter.   One of the best "everyday" beers (bought in a six-pack at normal price).   I get real annoyed when brewers try to Americanize English styles... however this one is done correctly and is delicious!  Lighter body, very drinkable, lots of lively carbonation.   Light malt character with loads of fresh piney bittering hops and a decent amount of citrus for depth.

12oz bottle.  Pours a clear golden with a white head.  Nose is of pine hops and some citrus.  taste is similar to a dry-hop IPA with citrus and pine hops balanced with sweet caramel.  Mouthfeel was medium with a nice, crisp, but not harsh, bitterness to it.  Wish I had more.

A big surprise.  I thought I was in for a hideously malty Octoberfest style ale, which in my opinion is the worst style of beer on the market.  Harvest ale was light, fresh with a citrusy hop aroma and a flavor of a pale ale or even a nicely hopped pilsner.  I was so happy to experience this beer, that I will go out tomorrow and buy a sixer for the first Ohio State Football Game.

bottle from my new craft brew outlet, Canal’s in Lawrenceville.  Pours clear and light copper and supports a medium and dense white head.  Initially, the aroma is very much that of an IPA.  Hoppy, citrusy and piney.  The flavors run in the IPA pack as well with a burst of grapefruit giving way to mild caramel and toasted malt.  The texture seems thin but enjoyable and the finish is modestly dry and crisp.  I wouldn’t peg this for an ESB as it fits more closely along the lines of a hoppy pale ale or IPA.  Style designation aside, this is a refreshing beer and another top tier offering from Southern Tier.
Pours a really nice golden sun colour, nice soft aromatic wheat with a pleasent mouthfeel that reminds me of summer. Very refreshing, clean finish and a citrus fruit character throughout the beer.

Poured a golden color with medium head and some lacing.  Aroma was lots of different types of citrus fruits.  Flavor was bitter hops and a lot of them pine and citrus.  Not a bad one just not my fav ST

Oct. 2007 - Pale yellow pour with some head and lacing. The flavor was light grapefruit nectar with zingy bitterness. Thick and syrupy mouthfeel, maybe too much so. Just okay. Not my favorite ST offering.

Very clear golden with small white head that last. Aroma is grainy, bready, with lots of fresh floral hops. Flavor is much the same floral hops with a touch of citrus and grapefruit and just a clean malt bill with a biscuit breadiness and a clean crisp maltiness. Just a standard pale ale but not bad at all.

1-19-08 bottle shared with lb4lb thanks to Miketd 

Slightly foggy pale yellow with a watery head and rings of lacing.  Nice hop apricot smell but a bit too subtle for my liking.  Taste is decent, doesnt taste very hoppy or memorable, for that matter.  Strange medicinal aftertaste.  Very watered down flavor.  Palate just isnt strong or bold at all.  I just wanted all aspects to be stepped up a bit.
Southern Tiers Harvest Ale is a very good American pale ale that i bought in a Southern Tier variety pack

Bottle courtesy of Miketd. Thanks!
Pours yellowish gold with a lasting white head.  Lighter than expected and looks much like a lager.  Smell is grassy, earthy hoppiness, and mildly so.  Taste is somewhat mild, and not very "green" or spicy like I like fresh hop beers.  Melon and tea flavored hops mostly with some earthiness and mild bitterness.  A bit watery and muted flavorwise, but this is very drinkable with no offensive qualities.  Decent Pale.

12 oz bottle courtesy jerc. Pale golden colour with a fully lasting creamy and frothy white head  intriguingly pale for what I thought was an IPA. Lovely aroma  orange, lime, tangerine, leafy, grassy, almost herbal, and lightly candyish with toasty notes. Light toasty malts that let the citrus, grassy, herbal, and piny bitter finish do most of the talking. Medium bodied, firm but juicy and refreshing mouthfeel. A nicely quaffable hoppy pale ale.

Not what I was expecting from the nondescript bottle. Pungent Goldings hops with a tasty, candyish malt base and a great full body. Some grass, some spice, some caramel...a good everyday APA. Very well realized.

Bottle courtesy of Jerc: Poured a deep hazy dirty yellow color ale with a huge foamy head with good retention and some lacing. Aromas of green hops are dominating with some nice floral notes. Taste is also dominated by some bitter green hops with some floral notes. Body is full with some limited filtration and great carbonation. Very well done for the style and something that I wish was available more readily around me.

[749-20071010] 355mL. Very grainy sweet citrus grapefruit hops aroma has a hint of sweat. Clear, pale orange brown body with a medium-lasting foamy white head. More sweet navel orange rind hops in the flavour with a touch of lemon. Light-medium body is only a little bitter. Very drinkable.

12 oz Bottle. Nice salted passionfruit and pineapple aroma. Blistering with hot, juicy tropical fruit. Light herbal qualities. Nice. Pours a very clear gold, even. Lacy white webbing drips off of the glass. Flavor is dominated by similar bright fruitiness now mingled with resin, citrus pith, and grasses. Body is lightly thin. Thin, vaporous alcohols alight the mid-palate. Moderately complex and dry. Theres a palpable thinness that makes it dangerously drinkable, and completely fitting for an APA. I should have served this colder. Cellar temp isnt working. This has an awful lot of flavor and complexity for an APA. Nicely dry and quaffable. Spicy on the palate, in a Moroccan way. Nice hop utilization overall, backed with a few fruity esters and the light malt is very clean and fresh tasting. A great rendition. A lightly filtered edge. Thanks Sean!
12oz bottle. Poured a deeper and hazy golden/orange color with an averaged sized off white head. Aromas of floral green hoppiness, citrus, and pine. Tastes of citrus, caramel, and a little earthy.

Thin white head of small bubbles.  Very good corbonation.  Looks great in the glass.  Sweet citrusy hops.  Lots of orange, grass and yeasty notes.  Color is a crystal clear dark gold.  Crisp and dry palate.  Good helping of bitterness and lots of fresh astringent hops.  Makes the mouth pucker a little.  Bitterness is a little bit on the harsh side though.  Finishes dry and bitter with a little bit of pasty film residue.  A decent brew.

12oz bottle courtesy of eaglefan538. Citrus hops open the nose for this one. Hazy gold body with white head and good amount of lacing. Fresh citrus grapefruit juice flavor that refreshes the palate. Good brew thanks Brian.

12 oz bottle.  Pours a very light golden with a mod carbonationa dn nice tight white head with good lace.  Aroma is tons of citrus hops, resinous with some pine sol.  Hardly any malt in the flavor either- mostly just resinous fresh harvested hops- a bit green and vegetal but mostly just fresh citrus hops, with lots of earth and tea drying bitterness in the end.  Nice APA!!!

UPDATED: FEB 11, 2009 12oz bottle-A golden body with a nice two finger white head which has an aroma of hops and more hops. A light body with the tast of citrus, grapdfruit, sweetness, and more hops. Great overall flavor. One of the better ESBs Ive tasted.
12oz bottle.  Light golden color.  Floral and dry, with a crisp, spicy finish.  Aggressively bitter without the hop syrup flavor in other big beers.  Very drinkable, and pretty unique.

Another good beer from Southern Tier. Fruity, citrus aroma with light grainy malt. Clear, bright, golden-yellow pour with a thick white head and cloudy lacing. Light and fresh on the palate, snappy and crisp with a nice bitter bite. Mellow and easy going, its a real drinkable beer. Familiar flavor of pine with lemon and orange. Fresh hop taste with a mild malt backbone. Sort of has a dry wheat quality as well.

Bottle.  Poured an orange hued golden with a thin off-white head that laces well.  A sweet citrusy hops aroma.  Taste is very fresh, herbal hops, not overwhelming and leaves a trace of nice resiny bitterness.

Was looking forward to this beer after hearing about it on a Podcast "The Good Beer Show".  What a find.  Looks like a typical light colored Ale, but it smells wonderful.  You can really smell the hops and some citrus tones.  Its light in the mouth, but man does it pack a punch of hoppiness.  Wonderful Beer, wish it was fall all the time.

Bottle. Body-light golden hue with a one inch foamy white head. Nose-good clean stale hops, cabbage, light cereal. Very nice clean nose. Taste-crisp, light hops (nice to see a beer that doesnt ram hops down your throat), light 7-up, light citrus, medium soft bitterness, almost creamy. Very well done, and well crafted. Quite enjoyable. Would be a great session beer.

UPDATED: NOV 16, 2007 (Bottle)  Pours a clear yellow body with a medium fluffy egg-white head and nice lacing.  Aroma of pineapple, apricot, toasted oats, orange, caramel, and grapefruit.  Flavor of citric/piney hops, biscuit, tea, and caramel with a soft mouthfeel and a bitter finish.

Bottle pours slightly cludy golden with pure white head, lots of lacing. Smells citrusy. Medium body, sharp carbonation. This is fairly bitter (grapefruit., mostly), but has a prickliness to it. Its starnge. Also, theres some malt underneath. Its not just one-dimension of grapefruit bitterness. I like it.

Harvest Ale is a hazy golden ale with a fluffy white pillow of a head that has great retention and leaves nice lacing.  There are small particles near the bottom of the glass.  The aroma is fresh and fruity.  It yields powerful pine resin, tangerine and grapefruit.  There is a slight starchy malt presence in the nose.  It is soft and medium bodied in the mouth.  There is barely any fizziness and the finish is dry.  The bitterness is not as intense as the aroma suggested it would be.  Still, the hops are pronounced with the same elements as the aroma.  It is juicy and fruity and fresh and bitter.  The balance in the flavor is a bit on the treble side, which makes this focus primarily on the bright, lemon peel quality and not on any spice or rumble.  Its simple.  This is an excellent session ale!  Where did that 6-pack go?

12 oz. bottle. Clear light gold under a medium white head that settles quickly, but leaves a nice sticky lace. Very hop dominated aroma with citrus and spice over a light toffee. Medium body and light carbonation, a bit resinous, and a dry palate. Bitterness rules, but is not excessive, well supported by a light malty base. This isnt at all what I expected, and I was pleasantly surprised. Very drinkable and refreshing.
Though I am not a hophead, I appreciated the thought and care that went into this one.

This beer is a bit different than a good number of APAs Ive had.  It isnt a total thick, syrup-y hop-bomb (and I love those...) and it also isnt light and insipid.  And it suprised me...its appearance led me to believe it would be light and flavorless, and it was hoppy and very light and drinkable.

This beer is a light gold color, totally clear, and brilliant.  It looks like a blonde ale from a large brewer might look like, and looks more than a little like a Budweiser or MGD.  Even the head is industrial looking - it is composed of uniformly sized bubbles of a medium size (think the head on a glass of Sprite).  It is a bit fizzy and has limited staying power.  "Uh-oh," I thought.  "I dont think Im going to like this."  The beers smell started to change my mind.  Lightly sweet and substantially hoppy with a lot of pineapple and citrus notes.  Flavor was a very light hoppy fruitiness backed with some malt.  It had very pleasant APA flavor and middle-of-the-road intensity.  Mouthfeel was exceedingly light and this beer was immensely drinkable.  This beer was proof to me that brewers can make something as light as a mainstream lager but still very flavorful.  

Definitely recommended.  Highly "unique," but not in a challenging way.

Bottle.  Pours clear, light gold with a very thin white head.  Godd hoppy aroma for an APA, a little citrus, pine and resin.  Flavoris nice and hoppy as well, lots of pine, not much of a malt presence. Great hoppiness, reminds me of a lighter Alpha King. Finishes a little watery, some bitterness.  Good beer, I like.
golden color, some decent foam nice hop nose nothing crazy but definatly there some good bread malts citrus with a decent malt backbone good mouth feel nice beer.At Joes

pours a light amber ith a white head.  flowery hoppy aroma with notes of fruit.  taste is great, very well balanced with hops, pine, malt, and light fruits.  medium bodied with a smooth mouthfeel.  gentle bitter aftertaste, refreshing.  YUM!

12oz.  Pours pale yellow with a small, bubbly white head. Standard looking beer.  Aroma is freshly hopped with a strong biscuity malt background.  Hops are grassy and thick.  Strong malt in the background too with the biscuity smell with some vanilla too.  Nice aroma and fairly unique.  Aroma is smooth, slightly grainy, lots of malt character with a smooth, semi-bitter hop flavor.  Easy to drink and pretty refreshing.  Nothing earth shattering but a very good example of the style.

Bottle. Very pale straw color with a thick white head and excellent lacing.  Begins with a slight malt aroma that leads to hop aroma. Starts with a short initial malt sweetness that gets hoppy and bitter quickly. This is an enjoyable blend of malt and hops, very flavorful. It has a solid dry finish that lingers with hoppiness.

12 ounce bottle form kmweaver
Pour light hazed yellow tiwh a lasting sticky white head.
Fantastic aroma.  Pineapple, peach, apricot, toast, and nuts
Balanced flavor with lightly sweet malt and peachy hop flavor.  Easy going bitterness.
Palate is light and refreshing.  Crisp finish.
I understand the whole fall harvest deal, but Id love to have this beer all summer.

light golden appearance with slight carbonation.  nose is somewhat but not overwelmingly hoppy.  flavor has only a slight malt initial character with a strong hop finish, almost has an fruity orange finish to it.  the beer is solid, but nothing extraordinary and the high rating here surprises me.
12 oz bottle from Odeed; Thanks Jake; nose of citrus and light piney hops; clear yellow-gold with a medium white head; flavor of grapefruit and piney bitterness. Pretty good APA!

bottle from rudolf: pours a golden hazy  hue with  nothing more than a thin white line for a head. aroma of grapefruit and malts with just a touch of toastyness. not much else going on but very enjoyable. flavour is a bitter grapefruit hop with some malt. flavour resembles aroma. avery enjoyable drinking beer with a good bitterness.

Gold, creamy white head.  Nose held fresh grassy citric tones that warmed to lighter pine and toasty caramel notes.  Grassy earth-like hop flavor balances on a light sweet malt backbone.  A touch of citrus creeps back in in the last half of the pint.  Light to medium bodied, soft carbonation, dry, lightly bitter finish.  A pale ale thats nice for football Sundays...

Bottle courtesy of shadey. Golden-orange with dense white head, great lacing. Aroma all citrus zest up front, grapefruit, orange, lemon. Faint pils-malt like background. Up front flavor is exactly what aroma suggests, slight oxidation/astringency in the finish detracts a bit, (would have been a 4.2 for me otherwise). Hop profile for APA is pretty big, probably pushing the limit, almost IPA. Oily smooth mouthfeel but finishes crisp, highly sessionable APA.
Solid pale ale.  Weak overall, but drinkable.  Hope notes with slight malt hangin out.  Went down smooth enough with a weaker then expected hop flavor.  Lite citrus, less then I hoped.

LIght golden color with a smallish, but stable white head. Rudy red grapefruit and lemon zest dominate the aromas. Hints of sweet pale malt in the background. Not the typical scent that I would expect from a "harvest" ale, but a rather nice surprise. Im starting to wonder if I like it because it is different or because I really do like it. I think I like the difference. Sweet malt and lemon soap in the flavors followed again by a burst of malt and sweet somewhat floral hops. Finish is somewhat dry with quite a bit of bitterness left on the tongue along with fresh green hops residue. A solid APA.

12oz bottle.  Pours a brilliant and clear, orange-tinged golden color; white head with good retention and shiny, cascading lacing.  Fresh, resiny hop aroma: grapefruit and citrus: not even the slightest astringency.  For starters, this beer reminds me so much of Buckeye Amarillo IPA (which is now my baseline of clean hops): clean, orangey and citrus hoppiness throughout; great resins and hop oils, with just enough malt to keep things afloat; just incredibly drinkable and good.  Seems more like my conception of an IPA; just lacking a little depth.  Medium, refreshing, light orange hop finish.
Very hoppy when ice cold, but evens out as it warms.  I really wasnt expecting all the hops, but in the end it works well.

Bottle at RFD Washington DC, 10/6/07. Pours an attractive deep golden with a frothy white head. Fresh, grassy, herbal hop nose - not intense, but nice. Has a simple malt profile to showcase the hops; notes of pale brewing malt, a light touch of bread/graininess then fresh grassy, floral hop character. Seems like a mix of noble and American hop varieties. Well attenuated, not that sweet - assertive yet non-harsh bitterness. Medium/light body with a smooth texture and lively carbonation. An ideal session, everyday drinkin beer. I wish I can get cases of this for the entire summertime.

Bottle.   Pours an amber color with a smallish white head.   Aroma is huge floral hops, grapefruit, caramel.   Flavor is again grapefruit, lemon zest, caramel.   Palate is medium bodied, medium carbonation, crisp and refreshing, finishes with a profound hop bitterness.   Very good!

Bottled.  Poured clear lighter golden with a short cap of white head.  The aroma picked up a soft, very pleasant light fruit and grapefruit backing that supported pine and grapefruit from the hoppage.. nice and sweet.  The flavor lost a step, but only one.. caramel and grapefruit sweetness with rising pine and juicy light fruit bitterness as it warmed up.. quite bitter and refreshing on the finish.  Light-medium bodied with a sweet and bitter finish.  Good stuff!

12oz. bottle, from both shadey and hopson (thanks guys!).  Pours a BRIGHT yellow golden, almost flourescent it seems; with a thin white head and good lacing.  Aroma is crisp citrusy hops.  Flavor is more hops, with a milder, albeit nice, lingering spicy bite.  Crisp and clean on the palate.  A very solid and tasty APA for fall.

The color was a golden color.  The head was off-white.  The aroma was hoppy, apricot, and citris.  The flavor was apricot/peachy, hoppy, citris, and few acidic notes.  The palate was smooth and refreshing.  The finish was clean.

UPDATED: SEP 25, 2011 Pours a clean sharp golden yellow with one finger of offwhite head. Spicy and citrusy nose with some pine resin and sweet malt. Resinous piney flavor with citrus zest and oily hop character. Medium body with a piney nose.

(bottle from shadey,thanks for re-sending it man!)murky yellow with a bit of a white head,but not much.aroma is dust,hay,bitter hops,and caramel malts.the flavor does much of the same with a bit of a 7-up type lemon/lime bite.
poured a nice golden hue with a white head.  Aroma was mostly malts with a nice hop background.   Flavor was initally fruity but finished with a really nice hop profile.  Very smooth.
Bottle. Golden with a white head. Aroma is ctirusy. Strong ctirus hop flavor with a long bitter finish.

Whew! A nice a delicious change of pace. I would not classify this as an APA though. Aroma was all hops. Nothing else. Pour was an amazingly light gold with a one finger white head. Taste was very hoppy with nothing else. Actually I tasted a lot of lemon..not vaguely citrus, but lemon. No malt at all. While I love this beer and the taste, I associate APAs with heavy malt taste. This is more like an EPA if anything.
user_location: Moon Twp, suburb of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, USA

text: UPDATED: SEP 28, 2007 White skin on a clear body of sunshine.  Wafts a summery orchard.  Nectarine, bitter peach skin, and cotton candy.  Rich, smooth caramel.  Bitter, tight, and simple flavor akin to an unsweetened and oversteeped black tea.  Pungent, old fruit and a burnt toffee sweetness.  Quickly, a thick smoke of wet autumn leaves and grass clippings intrudes and rests heavily.  Certainly flimsy malts.    A fleeting, foul whisper of diacetyl before the finish.  Bitterness with no character, and some sweet corn in the post-script.  Crisp and somewhat light texture doesnt lend a lot of interest.  Earthy, and bitterly herbal.  A few flaws, and not even that bright for what it is.

bottle from shadey...pale yellow orange with a quickly disappearing white head. grapefruity hop aroma is very light and sweet. light to medium bodied. flavors of brewed tea, sweet malts, straw and undefinable spices. lightly bittered hops on a dry finish.

12oz. bottle - pours almost crystal clear pale gold with a fluffy white head that leaves lots of lacing in the glass. Impressive. Flavour is earthy American hops with some orange and quite a bit of spice. Piney and fresh. Flavour is similarly piney, some light citrus/grapefruit notes, earth, and mild bitterness. Malty body comes through in the middle and integrates perfectly with the hop forward flavour. Warming. Medium body, smooth mouthfeel. Very good beer.

12 oz bottle from shadey.  Clear, pale yellow/oragne with medium white head.  Aroma is citrusy, lemon, piney hops and mild caramel malt.  Pine hop flavor with grain, medium sweet, okay.  Medium to light body with sharp carbonation, a little chalky.  Okay, but I want more of a malt background.

Bottle.  Aroma is hop-standing, piney, spicey citric.  Pours golden with a light white head.  Flavor is yummy hoppy twist of spice and malty biscuit.  Palate is light and refreshing, actually brought a smile to my face after 8 hours of work.  Overall, very tasty, definitely worth having a few of these around.

(12oz bottle) Small white head atop crystal clear apple juice body.  Aroma is mild, medium sweet, grapefruit.  Taste is medium sweet, grapefruit, some caramel, light spice, bread.  Somewhat dry finish.  Light-medium body.  Not bad, but not sure why its highly regarded.

12oz bottle thanks to shadey for this extra. pours clear golden with fluffy white head. nose is hoppy, interesting blend of piney, spicy, leathery, and tropical fruit hop notes. flavor is pleasantly bitter with piney and spicy hop notes with soft biscuity malt back bone. mouth feel is soft and light. clean finish. this is better than last years. really solid.

Bottle. Pours yellow body with a moderate fluffy white head. Aroma of sweet lemon and grapefruit. Flavour is quite refreshing, moderate bitterness throughout, more light lemon and grapefruit from the hops. Finishes  a lot drier with light notes of astringency and alcohol that seem out of place. Average smooth palate. At first sip I thought I was in for an amazing glass, and at the end I was just happy to have enjoyed a rather nice one.

Light yellow color with a small head.  I have to take off on appearance because it looks like a light lager.  The smell however is fantastic.  You can smell it from a foot away.  Classic citrusy aroma, very inviting.  Its well balanced PA, but only in that it has a thin body and is moderately bittered to match.  There is big hop flavor though, as promised.  Pine, spruce, spicey, earthy flavor.  I dont pick up any caramel at all, I think this is either straight base malt or maybe just a touch of light crystal.  Has a very dry finish, flavor lingers a while and becomes a little unpleasant.  The idea that this beer is better than 98.5 % of other PAs is a joke.  Its an easy drinking extra pale ale but nothing spectacular.

Pours a golden color with a white head.  Aroma is of citrus hops, caramel, sweet malts, and some grassiness.  Flavor is lighter then I expected with not as much hop character as the nose led to believe.  It does have a slightly bitter finish.  Not my favorite from southern tier but still pretty good.

Clear, light golden body.  Small, frothy white head that settles to a thin film with a bubbly rim.  Spotty, snake-like lacing.  Grapefruit explodes onto the nose like few other beers I have experienced.  The aroma is like a freshly sliced ruby red grapefruit over a toasted wheat background, with faint hints of caramel.  The flavor again starts with sharp, bitter grapefruit, followed by drying wheat.  Lightly toasted caramel is present, though its simply a complimentary background flavor and it does not add much sweetness.  Medium-light palate that goes down smooth and finishes with a razor-sharp grapefruit kick.  Ultra-refreshing beer that would be perfect for the beach or poolside on a hot Florida day.  Very nice!

Draft at Brew Kettle. Poured clear golden color with an average fizzy white head that was mostly lasting with good lacing. Solid balanced grapefruit citrus hoppy aroma. Medium body with slick texture. Medium balanced bittersweet flavor with a medium smooth bitter finish of moderate duration. Solid drinkable brew.
12oz via shadey.  Pours yellowish gold with a bright white half finger head.  Nose is bold and fragrant with citrus and a bit of pine.  Overall tastes great, its a pretty big and complex APA.  Nice.

12 oz. bottle.  Pours a clear deep golden color with a medium sized off white head.  The aroma is citrus hops with a bit of pine as well.  The flavor is a solid mix of the citrus and pine hops with a decent malt backbone to keep it in balance.  Medium light mouthfeel.  Another solid beer from Southern Tier.

Bottle. Hazy amber color with a medium head. Good lacing. Aroma of grass, citrus and peaches. Fruity taste, peaches with caramel and grassy bitterness. Dry finish. Very fine, fresh flavor makes it a pleasure.
A dry, fruity, and hoppy APA that is very sessionable. The nose is full of fresh peaches and grapefruit. The palate is light to medium in body with a nice graininess. Long hoppy bitter finish.

clear pale yellow, white head leaves minimal lacing.  nice pine and lemon zest aroma.  the taste is moderate bitter over a grassy hop.  light to mod carbonation.  nice clean finish.  a solid apa, but nothing super unusual.   the malt character could be increased a bit.  has more of a ipa feel.  however, the clean finish is a plus.

12oz. Bottle:  Medium sweet aroma.  Smells of caramel malts and lots of hops.  Poured amber in color with a small, fizzy, white head that mainly diminished.  Hazy.  Sparkling.  Some small particles.  Flavor is lightly sweet and lightly bitter.  Tastes of caramel malts and Styrian Goldings hops, with a hints of dough, wheat bread, and sourdough pretzel.  Medium body.  Average texture.  Average carbonation.    Boring malt/hop finish.  Overall, a very average APA.

12 oz. bottle.  Pours a mostly clear gold with a moderate off-white head that lasted to the bottom of the glass.  Pleasant floral aroma.  Reminds me of grass and privet hedges in the Spring actually.  Flavor was grass with a little bit of citrus.  Lightly bitter at the finish.  Enjoyable.
Another very drinkable  brew from the local boys. Nice hoppy aroma. Hoppy flavor balanced by carmel malt and some bready earthy flavors. I like it a lot.

Bottle.  The pour into a lager glass initially disappointing in its standard looking macro-lagery-ness.  Basically gold, bubbly and with a surrendering foamy white head.  However, thereafter comes a pleasing aroma of bright citrusy and grassy hops above wafery malts. Flavor was light and clean, almost wheaty cereal malts with a decent infusion of hops, leaving some refreshing citrusy bitterness on the finish.  Not as caramely in the malt like almost every other APA, here instead concentrating on the hop side, which is a nice change of pace.  Quite the drinkable light yet hoppy session beer. This is going very well with football.

Anything by Southern Tier that I have not had a chance to try yet is an immediate purchase for me at this point. After being blown away by their imperial series and impressed by everything else (except the raspberry brew), I am all for trying another production.

Pours a crystal clear straw gold with a nice white head that has some staying power. Nose is perfumed floral hops in abundance, but not shoving it all down, errr...up your nose. Flavor has a nice balance to it, though it is a bit hop forward. Mild bitter tone there. More than mild, but not overly pronounced leafy character as well. Feel has a pretty full carbonation to it and a decent liquid body. A definite fall time brew. Even though it is still summer weather, I drink this on and feel like fall is almost on me. Another good one by ST.
On tap @ Coles, Buffalo NY. Nice hop aroma. Medium body & hop flavor. Piney some grapefruit. Good APA

12 oz bottle.  Clear, then cloudy, yellow brown with a bubbly, off-white head.  Peachy caramel and grass.  Medium body with a honey mouthfeel.  Soft carb buzz.  Vanilla, toffee and candied orange peel play off pine and juicy grapefruit.  Barleywine light.  Sweet but not cloying.  Very nice.
Potent hop aroma - coupled with floral notes and a nice grassiness. Highly filtered, barely a head at all.  Very mild in flavor, with lots of flowers and hops.  Clean and tasty, easy to drink.

Thanks to Eugene for recommending this beer; I would have passed it up otherwise - completely clear pale golden beer with a small ring of lace (could probably pass for a pale lager based on looks) - spicy, peppery hop aroma, with some buttery notes and light floral touches - the flavor is a strong, grassy, spicy hop showcase, with just enough malt sweetness to keep the beer from being too dry - the beer remains crisp and finishes rather clean, keeping the hops the star of the show all the way through - a nice, flavorful quaffer, perfect for late summer or early autumn.

Appearance: hazy orange, whispy head
Aroma: sweet piney malt aroma with a bit of grapefruit
Body: thin body
Flavor: lots of lingering bitter flavor, touch of piney sweetness but not enough to bring balance
Overall: too thin and bitter overall

Aroma: perfect sugared grapefruit aroma

Overall: totally friggin awesome, they may have started with an esb but then hopped the hell out of it, fresh makes a difference
