Rated while drinking: Pours a clear gold color with a big fluffy white head. Aroma is ultra hoppy and sweet smelling. Almost spicy-like in character. Pretty aromatic! Lots of flavor notes in here. Sweet pastries lead in, followed by some sort of exotic sugar, and tapers off with grass/herb notes. Very complex for an APA. Smooth on the palate the whole time, until bitterness kicks in at the swallow. Trademark ST freshness too! Aftertaste and feel is well done. Easy to sip or slam. Pretty blown away by this beer. Best one of the night so far, and I have a feeling it will keep that title as well. I really like these Southern Tiers; they do a remarkable job for a NY microbrewery.

Whoa- is this a Budweiser- it looks like a bud.....But wait!!! Serious smells of cascade/cent hops. This is no bud at all. Great flavour, and a nice sessionable abv. What a nice beer, and no surprise, considering this brewer is always churning out high quality.

UPDATED: AUG 27, 2007 Color is completely lucid pale, reaching into macro-looking territory. Just some spit in place of lacing, not nice looking.  Aroma is awesome though, I dont know how they did it but its strong on hops but they are not assertive on your nose.  First comes citrus and lightly resin-y hops, then some floral/grassy German-like hoppiness and just a hint of sweet light-summer honey.  Not aggressive, more of a misty feeling to the aroma.  Taste is soooo light and yet full of flavor, more on the floral/grassy side with a good strong carbonation and felt bitterness to round it all off.  Light and refreshing and definitely has a hoppy Pilsner (or very light Maibock) feel.  Aftertaste is lightly white bread sweet with lingering grassiness. I could probably replace water with this beer, very nice brew, probably the best I have had from Southern Tier. 12oz bottle, Southampton shaker.
user_location: HdG (past: NYC, KS, Rain City), Maryland, USA

text: Very pale straw coloured brew.  Sticky lacing.  Very fresh hop aroma, zesty lemon citrus, and rich herbal/noble character.  Very pilsnerish in its hop selection.  Lots of earthy/flowery hops with a bit of soft raspberry-like sweetness.  Very fresh with lean crisp malts letting the hops shine through.  Ill be buying more of this one, I guarantee.

Golden yellow colour with off white head. Slight musty aroma with malts. The hops are not strong and overpowering, hops is present but is not hidden. Light hop bitterness in the flavour with a clean refreshing palate with light acidicy.
Pours with and orange-gold body topped by a thin head with some lacing.  Its bitter and hoppy with a piney note, a little grass and a touch of malt.  Light to medium bodied, smooth and dry.

Light golden in color with a thick and frothy white head. Resinous and sticky aroma - very inviting. Sweet malt base is a nice platform for the agressive hoppiness of this ale. Lots of grass and lemon tang, with some residual dryness

12 oz bottle via trade with Jah Noth (Thanks!) A fruity hop nose at first,  grapefruit, light and citrusy, with a definate pine note to the hops.  Pours a clear golden color with a rocky white head that lingers.  Taste is the bitter hopped out flavor is what comes to the forefront. Less of the fruitiness that you get in the aroma is not very prevalent in the taste.  Somewhat grainy and gritty too.  Palate is definitely bitter with a long lasting aftertaste.  Overall, Solid but not stellar.  Theres something weird about the taste that I cant put my finger on but its a sort of a twang.

Bottle.  Chewy, fruity hop, honey and wheat nose.  Chewy and peppery taste, a bit overcarbonated, but has a nice husky grain, wheat and chewy orange-flavored hop taste.  Nothing spectacular, but still enjoyable.

(Bottle) Courtesy of a trade with Blankboy. Really been looking forward to this beer. Read a lot about it but never seen it at the numerous Northern NY beer fests? Pours a foamy, almond-coloured thin head. It doesnt really dissipate much - nice retention. Clear light golden colour. Nose is very fruity, very citrus, very orange. Flavour of sharp orange hops with a watery after-palate followed by a slight bitter hop finish. Everything you need in an APA. Lovely stuff.

From a 12oz Bottle.  Pours a very clear honey gold color with a soapy layer of brilliant white head.  Gardeny aroma of goldenrod pollen and perfumy iris stalks blend nicely with some pithy orange atop a gently baked barley malt base.  Light bodied, well carbonated mouthfeel with a cleansing prickle.  Fresh hop flavors abound among the light malt base.  Very tasty.  The hops give it a nice dark pithy character with a touch of almost rye-ish spice.  A long herbal spicy finish rounds this out nicely.
I got a growler of this from the 6 pack house of beer (West) in erie. I wasnt impressed as i had been with other souther tier brews but for a autumn seasonal i guess it was decent.

UPDATED: FEB 1, 2007 Bottled at Oliver Twist, Stockholm.  Clear golden, firm small head. Citric grapefruity hop aroma. Sweet with clean mouthfeel. Lots of hay and grapefruit from the hops. WIth its interesting sweaty hay character it gets reminiscent of an Americanized Hook Norton Haymaker. Lingering bitter finish. In many Southern Tier I have found the malt profile to be too hard and clean, but in this beer the mouthfeel is a little more rounded and the crispness feels more appropriate.

Pour is a yellow color with a fizzy white head.  Hoppy and earthy aroma suprised me a little with the nice hop presence.  Medium palate puts a hoppy, crisp, clean brew on display.  The finish is dry.  This is very drinkable and pleasant.

Nice citrus hop aroma, with an undertone of tannin.  Very pale, small head, and moderate carbonation in the appearance of the beer itself.  But the flavor is there, sharp crisp hop tastes slowly fading away.  I really wish this was available year round.

12 oz bottle from Shadey.  Smell was fairly faint, but it did smell fresh. The color was pale, even moreso than Is typically seen in a pale ale.  Flavor was slightly hoppy, with some nice spices going on.  I kind of liked this.
Get some slight hops in the aroma.Pours a light yellow color with a big white head.Get some lemon and hops in the flavors.A little thin with some nice hops in the finish.

Courtesy of Santa.

Body is a bright apple cider yellow, clear with a partially bubbly white head that is mostly lasting.

Aroma is all citric hops and scant else.

Fresh piney hop flavor in the fore, mild citrus notes of both orange peel and sweet grapefruits. Some mild malt sweetness, but this is mostly about hops and not really my personal favorite as far as approach.

Bottle. Pours a slightly hazy golden-orange with an average size lasting white head. Nice, slightly mild, hoppy aroma.  Flavour has a good hop and malt balance, its quite refreshing and easy to drink. Medium bodied. A true session ale.

Draught sample at the Blue Tusk in Syracuse, NY, early October 2006.  Pours a pale, bubbly yellow with just a trace of lasting head....massive hoppy-fruity, acidic nose, pungent with drying/rotting apricots and fresh barnyard scents, dry citrus.....on the tongue at first its quite dry also, a little dull and lifeless briefly but a nice light sweetness develops in the clean mouthfeel and huge bitterness shows up towards the finish....moderate to high carbonation, a bit boring at finish but on the whole this works.

(bottle - 12 oz) Dark gold in color with a thin white head. Aroma is lightly hopped with some citrus, pine, and resin. Flavor has a good amount of floral and bitter hops at the beginning, a pine and citrus flavor in the middle and a very dry and bitter finish. Its been a while since Ive had the regular Harvest Ale, but whats the change? Still good though.

This was a nice beer but was thin bodied for a pale ale.  Interesting though in that it packed all of the hop flavor of bigger beers.  Well worth a try.Earlier Rating: 10/19/2006 Total Score: 3.7Very nice beer.  Poured a golden orange color with a thin white head.  Looks are deceiving with this one, as the taste is far from plain.  A very good beer.
This is a great beer for fall.  I really enjoyed tatsing this and likened it to when I first had a real micro brew.  You will be happy!

Bottle (12oz).  2006 version: twist-off, a raised "06 near the base of the bottle, neck-label.  Pale clear gold, small white head.  Aroma of alcohol, citrus/spruce hops, a resiny tangy malt, almost a hint of turpentine.  Taste of herbal/grassy hops with a strong background of pine & resin, very restrained, tangy lemony malt, alcohol, everything restrained, much alcohol bitterness in the finish.  Watery body, astringent, slick, alcoholic mouthfeel, very silky yet the linger is almost teeth-squeakingly crisp.  Very good, I think the alcohol would mellow and some woody character might come into it on aging.  Earlier Rating: 11/5/2005 Total Score: 3.9Bottle (12oz).  Rich, oily-looking gold with a thin white head.  Aroma of rich, oily-resiny-grapefruit hops, yeast, some roast malt - very appealing.  Taste follows nose, but is very muted - lighltly oaky, almost like a malty harvest ale, only alcohol-light.  I find no flaws and its  quite complex as it warms, average body and a nice oily mouthfeel.  This ones eminently drinkable.

A gift from a traveling friend. When I poured this I was expecting a pumpkin beer. A nice slightly redgold pour. When this beer arrived I thought it was a pumpkin beer. I was pleasantly surprised to catch an aroma of citrus almost lemon with a nice touch of hops.  A big hops flavor dominates but it has a citrusy whang with a tad of malt. Very hoppy for the style but very very nice.

Bottle, thanks to a buddy. Pours out a nice clear light copper color with a small white head. Floral hops on the nose. Nice mouthfeel with a good complex taste. Very good balance, grassy/floral hop taste with some caramel and slight nut flavors with a bit of a hop kick on the finish. Very solid beer.
A very nice surprise, big hop nose with a bit of sweet graininess like wheat extract. Taste is  full of delicious hops and leaves a bit of bitterness on the tongue. A very nice brew indeed.

Bottle - courtesy of HogTownHarry. Clear, pale golden with a small white head - lighter looking than I expected, but OK. Really interesting hop aroma - its orangey, but more like orange candy than actual oranges. Quite nice, really. Flavour is quite bitter at first, with lots of citrus and pine, but there are some sweet malts in there as well that start to come through as it warms. A bit of grassiness as well. Good stuff - thanks for the bottle, Harry!
One bottle from trade with JB.  Poured a small white head.  Hop aroma.  Flavor of hops overpowered everything else for me.  Bitter ending.

12oz bottle (thanks to Jah Noth) poured a clear golden color with a slightly off white head. Big aromas of grassy citrus and pine hops with a touch of malt. Taste had a good strong hop character along with some nice caramel malt flavores. Almost tastes like an IPA, with a dry hoppy finish and good malt balance, but not too strong in alcohol. Overall one of the better harvest ales.

Bottle from Sam the Beer Man. The grapefruit and some hoppy notes resonate with a good dose of carbonation and a somewhat yeasty flour-like tone going down. This one doesnt smack me with bitter hops and seems a bit toned down for an APA but its refreshing at the same time. The medium creamy finish with those citrusy apricot-flavors makes this one stand out.

12oz bottle - slightly hazy straw yellow color with smallish pure white head. Aroma has notes of grapefruit, lemon, chamomile, mint, with a touch of earthy grains. Flavor is slightly grainy, with a bit of grapefruit, lemon, note of juicyfruit gum. FInish is balanced, with a subtle hint of bitterness. A decent brew, but Im not quite sure how I would classify it. It doesnt seem like an APA to me, almost has wit-like qualities.

2006 vintage:(twist off, neck label, new cap, 06 emobssed on glass).  Poured a clear gold with a medium almost white head.    Aroma of citrus/pine hop combo with caramel and oranges in the malt.  short malty start with a moderate pine hop middle.  For the finsih the malt comes back with a good balance to the pine.  The finish is semi-dry, long and moderately bitter.  This is very tasty and easy drinking while giving a fair amount of hops.

12 oz. bottle via trade with shadey - Pours a very clear golden color with a small white head.  Light lacing and carbonation.  Has a citrus hop, soapy aroma.  Has a bitter citrus hop flavor.  Light, bitter, dry finish.  Light body.  Reminds me alot of 3Fs Gumbalhead.  A good beer.  Thanks Shane

Aroma of apricots and grapefruit.  Thin head with some lacing and light orange appearance.  Nice balance in the palate with buttery feel, malty sweetness and a gritty hops finish.Earlier Rating: 11/12/2004 Total Score: 2.7Pours out orangish-gold with a quickly disappating head.  Not that aromatic for an American Pale Ale.  Hops taste throughout but not as strong as some pale ales.  Nice clean finish, no bitter aftertaste.  Im not tasting the maltiness others report or seeing the bodacious head.

I just read the thread on this beer and I believe I have the 2006 because of the twist-off.  This does remind me of the great divide fresh hop.  It has a really organic, fart-like smell.  Light copper in color.  Medium-light body.  Flavor is moderately bitter, very malty and somewhat buttery.  Pretty good.

The beer pours to a completely hazy glowing golden body with a nice white head and awesome lacing.  Nice slow visible carbonation.  The aroma is piney and spicey with some barley and crystal malt aromas.  Perhaps some graham crackers.  The flavor is sweet with a buttery palate.  Buttered club crackers, graham crackers.  Really malty with a light spicy hop kick.  The palate is buttery and creamy with a nice lively carbonation.  Very nice brew.

Not sure why this has a special designation, but here goes.  Light golden in color with a thick and frothy white head.  Resinous and sticky aroma - very inviting.  Sweet malt base is a nice platform for the agressive hoppiness of this ale.  Lots of grass and lemon tang, with some residual dryness.  I have already purchased 12 of these and am enjoying them.  Shane, try another.Earlier Rating: 10/29/2003 Total Score: 4.3Lovely floral hop bouquet, rich golden color with a fluffy head.  Rich malt flavor with plenty of citric and piney hops.  With all due respect to those who rated before me, I belive this is a pale ale, and a darn good one at that.

UPDATED: JAN 1, 2013 *This beer has had two very different recipes, the original was a very nice IIPA.  Newer versions are a light and refreshing APA*

IIPA Rating: 9/2/2004 Total Score: 3.9Pour is an amber orange with a little bit of a white film on top that quickly receeds to the outside edge of the glass.  The aroma is mild hops.  Very clean tasting, very refreshing.  I should have bought about a case of this.  Great stuff.

IIPA Rating: Consumed 2008, almost 4 years old. Kept at cellar temps since its purchase in fall 2004. The top comes off with only a slight hiss. The pour is a hazy melon/gold with a thin head of white cream. The aroma has dulled but the hops are still detectable. There is a spicy hoppiness and almost a candy fruitiness. The flavor is definitely sweeter, but still really nice. Fruity, malty, and just a touch of spiciness. Good stuff for a brewery that was just getting started at the time. 6/3/6/3/14. 

2006 version. Pale yellow color with white creamy head. Aroma is different. Almost soapy smelling with some dried out dusty hops. Flavor is bitter hoppiness with a bone scrapping dryness to the finish. This was hugely dissapointing. Nothing like last years version. 6/3/5/3/14

2007 Version 12oz bottle fresh. Pour is a clear pale orange with minimal head.  Aroma is a pleasant fresh hops that is very fragrant.  The flavor is clean and crisp, very easy to drink.  The malts and hops play with each other very nicely.  This has VASTLY improved over last year. Congrats to Southern Tier - back on track. 7/3/8/4/17

2008 version. On Tap at the Flour City Beer Festival. The man pouring said it was only newly available a few days before.  Very fresh hop aroma that just bulldozes its way through my sinuses.  Really nice to smell.  The flavors reveal some of the other characters like pine and a touch of orange.  Very easy to drink and exciting all at the same time.  Its definitely at its best when as fresh as possible. 8/4/8/3/18

2009 version. Light bodied and grassy, citric hops. Drink fresh and drink often.

2004 version tasted 1/1/2013. 8yrs old. Still lightly carbonated. Aroma is sweet, a little stale. The spicy hops are still present. Im impressed!

Poured from the bottle a hazy light amber color with a never ending pillowy white head. I had to wait about 5 minutes to drink this because of the huge head. Aroma is nice fresh hops all the way, very inviting. Bitter hop flavor balanced with a mild sweetness, but yet the bitterness stays throughout very nicely. A nice mild hop bitterness, not a mouth-puckering bitterness.  I was told to try this after being a bit disappointed with an earlier batch. The 2006 version is definitely better -- nice brew.Earlier Rating: 7/20/2006 Total Score: 3.4This beer started off good and didnt finish as good as I expected. Poured from the bottle a slighty cloudy golden amber with thin head. I liked the piney hop aroma, that made my hop senses tingle. The flavor was a bit odd, the hops seemed to be at the end leaving a different dry bitterness which isnt usually a bad thing. i think this was missing a little malty sweetness to balance the bitterness a bit. I will have to try another because I think this has potential.

From a 12 oz. twist cap long neck brown bottle with no freshness date.

Poured a clear orangey golden with a foamy white head that settled into a thin lacing, minimal amount of sticking.

Hoppy aromas, earthy spicy, grapefruity and leafy, hints of pine and a very soft sweet malty way in the background.

A good moderate carbonation and a crisp, smooth lightish medium bodied mouthfeel.

Hoppy tasting with the hops soft in their bitterness, grapefruit, more zest than rind, an earthy pepperiness, hop leafy, the malts are subdued, sweet with touches of grain, and a spicy and leafy finish.

Not a bad fall APA, the hoppiness is soft enough to keep this from being an IPA, I personally could have use a touch more of a malt backbone, more malty flavor, but still very drinkability.

Bottle. Pours a translucent gold with a white head. I have a few hop vines, whenever I walk by, I pull off a cone, tear it open, and get a good whiff. The aroma here smells just like that fresh hop, along with some grapefruit and malt. Texture is  medium light.  Nice hop and malt balance. The pale malts blend well with the leafy and citrus hop bitterness. The herbal hoppy finish has a touch of sweetness. Goes down refreshingly smooth with no resinous or sticky lingering bitterness. Bold without being heavy.  Nice beer. Glad I bought a six. I could drink this shit by the case. Thanks for the recommendation Rudolf.

On tap at J.P. Bullfeathers. Pours a clear deep golden color with a medium fluffy white head. Floral hopped aroma with some caramel scents. Medium bodied, smooth taste. Well balanced dry hoppiness, bitterness and caramel sweets. This was defiantely a good beer, just didnt blow me away.

UPDATED: OCT 10, 2006 Sampled on Sep 24, 2006 and then again on Oct 10, 2006...

Ive heard so much talk about this beer and how good it was, that I had my manager pick up a sixer of it for me (he got the last one left at the store!)...  

Crystal clear golden color with lively carbonation and a foamy white head.  Aroma is fresh hops all the way (tangerine and pineapple) and apparent as soon as the cap is popped.  Its crisp, clean, and completely iniviting.  Flavor is a wonderful blend of malt and hops with a distinctive grapefruit flavor.  The hops are balanced and not overpowering.  Lots of great aromas and flavors in there including citrus, grass, some spiciness, and floral notes.  The bitterness builds from the start all the way through the finish inviting you back for more.  Palate is clean and mouthfeel medium to full - just great really.  This beer is bold, smooth, and oh so drinkable!  

This was the first Southern Tier beer Ive tasted and I was quite impressed.  Now I will have to go out and grab up a bottle of each of there other available brews and give them a taste!

Bottle:  Aroma has lots of pineapple and apricot with light caramel notes.  Almost smells IIPA-ish.  Pours a bright transparent golden-orange with a small white head that fades quickly.  Flavor has a light sweet citrus presence that is almost instantly overtaken by lots of hoppiness.  Grapefruit, pine, and flowers mingle together form a big hop finish that lingers on the palate for a while.  Flavor is more IPA and almost bordering on IIPA status.  Solid, but doenst look, smell, or taste like an APA.

Bottle: Clear golden orange, with a small white head. Aroma, pale malts, and a light fresh floral hop character. Flavor, crisp bitterness, some citrus, some floral notes, and some spicy hops. Lively carbonation, some lingering bitterness. Quite hoppy really. And pretty enjoyable.

Bottle from Sean, thanks.  Yellow beer that looks like a pale lager.  Smell is grass, hops, grapefruits, and sweetness.  Taste is apples mixed with grass.  A true session beer that could be slammed in a hurry, actually, on command.  Quite the session brew, one of the best Ive had.

Brilliant gold, decent sized white head. Nice citrusy hops aroma on a malty base, plus some savory notes, too. Nice hop flavor up front, then a bunch of interesting flavors after that - salt? cedar? smoke? i cant quite put my finger on it. Anyhoo, also an herbal character, too, and some quiet biscuity notes in the finish. Surprisingly full bodied considering how light colored it is. Sticky aftertaste. Really good, i could drink a lot of this. Thanks to Springslicker for this one!

An average sized white head forms easily over this brilliantly clear, light gold beer.
Spicy noble hop aroma.
The flavor starts with a mild sweetness and finishes with a long, building, dry bitterness.
An easy drinking beer thats hoppy, but not too hoppy.

12oz bottle pours golden with a tall whte head. Aromas of nice citrus, grass, and floral hops.  Flavor is a pretty hoppy experience as well with good citrus grapefruit, pineapple, and caramel malt.  Flavor is quite balanced between nice citrus hops and good sweet caramel malts.  Palate is light and pretty well carbonated..  Nice fall brew!

First rating oh yeah oh yeah. Pours a bright, clear gold, with a slight head. Aroma is of powerful pine-tar hops, cutting and fierce, an exhibiting characteristics of many vegetables, such as brussel sprouts, uncooked string beans, and stinky cheese, though of course that is not a vegetable. Minerally and sharp, bitter taste, hops are very floral and spicy, quite the opposite of the double simcoe I just quaffed. Very drinkable and swell.Earlier Rating: 10/4/2005 Total Score: 3.6I thought this would be a wheat so that was kinda dissappointing... still a nice beer. Aroma is sprucy, with a bunch of citrus/grapefruit, dough, though not very assertive. Pour is a nice gold with very minimal head. Taste is nice, with a full bitterness, pronounced hops, "zesty" as it says in the descirption. The beer has a weird kinda mouth puckering (though not in a sour way) kinda thing when I taste it... almost like the toothpaste/orange juice kinda deal, though not disgusting.
bottle. Odd aroma smells like a pale lager. Too pale of an appearance with very thin head. Taste is almost sour with an odd combination of hops. I really did not enjoy this.
Pours a nice golden yellow with a two fingered white head.  Aroma is hoppish with citrus and floral.  The flavor is lighlty hoppish with a touch of grapefruit and pine with some caramel maltiness.

Sample at AleFest Dayton: Bright golden color with a thin white head and minimal lacing. Citrusy hops aroma with roasted malt in the background. Light-bodied with a zesty character of herbs and spices and citrus. Nicely hopped but has good malt balance. The finish is hoppy yet sweet at times. Pretty good stuff.

Bright golden body with medium carbonation and a lush, foamy white head. Aroma of fresh-squeezed citrus, pine needles, and pale honey tones. Subdued, but building hop flavor.  Light peanut skin notes.  Mostly dry with lingering sylvan hops in the finish.  A good bottled harvest ale.

Soft bodied, ever so slightly cloudy. Not sure what I was expecting, but it wasnt this. not that its a bad thing in the least. Just a bit underwhelmed. For all the body it seemed most of the flavor was lurking somewhere below the surface. Thats probably just my hop beaten pallet talking ... Slightly sweet with hops emerging late in the finish. Nice beer and another I would very much like to try again to see if my opinion was different.
thanks again to Shadey

This has become one of my favorite fall seasonals.  Pours a pale golden color with a thick white head.  The aroma defies the pale appearance, and is actually pretty malty (caramel and bicuits) paired with lemon zest and spicy hops.  The flavor is definitely hoppy, with grapefruit and spruce taking the lead, but the hops mellow in the finish, with the sweet malts poking their head in just in time to smooth the finish.  The sweetness builds as the brew warms.  Slick mouthfeel, nice medium body.

bottle. thick orange-golden body, rather boring looking actually since the head quickly lowers to a small ring. grapefruit, resiny citrus hop aroma...also some toasty bread malt. mmmm, this is tasty. sweet chewy hops and a whole whack of earthy biscuilt malt. very balanced. superb.
clear gold, tight white head.  aroma of orange, flowers, doughy malt and toast.  flavours of honey, perfume, caramel, earth and toasted bread.  lemon and hoppy finish.  nice.

Pours clear gold with a short lived soapy head. Nose of piedough, spice, hops and bready sweet malts. Mouthfeel is very pleasant. The beer on a whole is straightforward but it is a great little beer. Lemon, sweet herb. Hop is pronouced but not overwhelming.  Bready malts. Some faint caramel. Very enjoyable.

Deep gold in color with a well-formed, well-sustained, creamy, white head.  Nice, spicy hop aroma with cascades very prominent.  Some sweetness, lightly chewy, lightly proteinaceous.  Good acidity.  Pretty striaghtforward, but pretty good as well.  Great for a long session.

Ive had this on tap in the Finger Lakes region and in the bottle.  This rating is from the bottle, but the bottle is pretty representative.  Deep golden color with a foamy white head and an orange citrus hop nose.  This beer has strong hop flavors with lots of orange, grapefruit and some berry flavors with caramel sweetness.  The bitter finish is of candied orange peel.  I like hoppy beers and this is a good hoppy beer.
drinkable hoppy grapefruit and floral aroma and apple juice/pineapple juice taste. Why the apple juice taste? Amber with white head.

decent, not memorable, amber color, nothing stale or off putting but no real signature either.  the hops are pretty timid in this one, was not sure what was in store, was hoping for more a a Sierra Nevada Celebration clone.  This would be loverd by neophyte afficianados though.

Clear, deep golden ale with a small, creamy, off-white head. Great retention. The nose, much like Southern Tiers Mild Ale rings of iced tea. Very fresh, mild hops with a hint of lemon. Perfectly balanced iced tea flavor with notes of lemon rind and very light toffee. Medium-bodied with a watery mouthfeel and medium carbonation. Lengthy, clean, dry finish. Extremely drinkable. Great session beer.

UPDATED: NOV 14, 2004 (12 oz bottle, obtained in trade with shadey, thanks Shane!) Not bad, not bad.  But not great either.  Its fairly flavorful, moderately hoppy with grapefruit overtones, and malty enough to somewhat balance the hops.  Neither of the components assert themselves.  This pale ale also has a sweet orange citrus flavor which starts off slowly, but comes on a bit stronger in the finish.  And as this beer warms to room temperature, a clear sweetness emerges, mostly in the finish.  Medium bodied, somewhat crisp from the hops, but not especially dry either.  I dont get too much in the way of aroma with this beer -- its vaguely malty, a bit hoppy, but pretty light overall.  The color is light amber, a bit hazy, with many medium-size carbonation bubbles hurrying their way to the top of the beer.  Pours to about half an inch of off-white colored head, somewhat creamy, with solid retention.  A dense curtain of lace is left on the glass.  This Southern Tier product is enjoyable enough, but not in the upper tier.

Light copper in color with a big fluffly white head, great lacing, had a slight hop aroma with a little sweetness, very smooth, light in body & mouthfeel, very drinkable, nice session beer, well-balanced, good hop character & nice malt flavor, deep malt aftertaste

Wow...! Where the hell did this brewery come from? Ive been drinking micro-brewed beers for about a year and a half now, and I only came across this lovely variety pack just a couple of days ago. I am VERY impressed with these beers, especially this one. My bottle says phin and matts extraordinary ale...and that it definately is. This is a very clean, crisp, unique ale that I found ver enjoyable. Could easily have a LONG session with this stuff. This is a damn fine brew plain and simple. Im not going to get all technical about the aspects of aroma and flavor, just go out and get yourself a case of this...youll thank me. Its about 30 bucks.

UPDATED: OCT 11, 2011 Every once in awhile, life treats us to a surprise.  And every once in awhile, those surprises exceed even our wildest expectations.  I bought this case of Southern Tier beers from Shangys because it was affordably priced, had a variety of 4 beers I had never tried, and I liked the labels.  The IPA has already knocked me out, and this one just goes over the top!  Again, my label is more modernized than the photo at left.  Pours slightly turbid gold with a medium white head and average lacing.  Gigantic aroma of hops, citrus, malt, pine, resin.  Tastes super hoppy, with a firm malt backbone and a crsip, smooth, piney finish, even a touch of Tanqueray gin.  I have two more Souther Tier beers to try from my variety case.  These beers destroy ass!  I know where two more cases are, and Ill be getting them tomorrow before anyone else hears about this.  This secret wont stay secret for long.

Re-rate 11-Oct-2011,, almost 7 years later.  Wow, this was one of my first 1,000 ratings!  How time flies.  Anyway, Im kicking this one down a few notches, as I had it again this weekend, and although I still love this beer, it is not a 4.6 beer, especially looking at my rating history.  I chalk this re-rate up to normalizing a very good beer that I initially rated too high due to childhood exuberance.  Still, a worthy harvest ale well worht the price and seeking out.

Bottled
A very hoppy nose and nice golden amber pour.  The hops smell fresh and the taste is pure hops with a slight malty backbone in the finish.  Great session beer for sure!

Poured amber with medium white head...smell is all hops with citrus (lemon) and floral...great aroma...taste is a little thin, but very well balanced...smooth malts and then a little hop bitterness near the finish...good APA!!

Bottle pours golden, fairly clear, medium foamy off-white head, attractive lacing, with minor carbonation.   Smooth hoppy aroma, with some very subtle spices.   Sharp flavor on first sip, but not biting.   Seems very clean.   Also slight citrus like spices.   Good body, decent mouthfeel.   Finishes with a nice hop smack, slightly spicy, with hints of pine or spruce.   WOW, a very nice pale ale with no grassy/graininess involved. &nbsp Clean, crisp finish. &nbsp Me like!   Thanks goes out to jah noth for the trade!

A very pleasant fall pale ale.  Full orange color - clear; medium head that settles to a short ring, great lacing.  Aroma is fresh citrus, herbal hops, wet malts.  Medium bodied - the flavors feel like theyre coating the entire mouth with sweet malts, orange peel, mellow grapefruit, apricots, and some herbal, almost medicinal hops.  For all of the hoppyness going on, theres still a big blast of malt to keep it even keeled.  Thanks for bringing this to me, Rudy!

A nice balance beween lightly sweet caramel malt and fresh hops in the aroma. Pours a glowing orange with a nice white head. Taste has a quick fruity malt start followed up by some bitter citrus hops. A very clean tasting brew with a slight grapefruit taste in the finish.

My bottle poured an orangey colour that looked just like autumn. The nose was a sensational hop bouquet with pine, spice and citrus. The flavour didnt quite live up to that initial promise, but I still enjoyed the nice initial hop kick followed by a solid malty flavour.

Bottle:  Light, clear, copper in color with a solid, off white head.  Very fresh aroma.  Citrus & floral hops, lemon, orange, candy sugar, bubble gum, and a nice earthyness round out the aroma.  Sticky taste, quite fresh and balanced taste.  Initially a bit sweet, though quickly afterwards the hops take over.  There some nice orange/citrus flavors here, reminds me of drinking dark, bitter tea - like when you leave the teabag in too long.  That bitterness works well with the juicy hops and solid malt backbone.

Hazy copper. Firm off-white 1cm head. Interesting hop dominated aroma with underlying earthy and cookie-ish malt. Hops come in orangey and rather floral. It has pretty much everything for me to enjoy it, tastes very fresh. Perhaps just a tad too bitter/tart for my tastes. Still, nice overall  balance I must admit, but I kept thinking (dreaming) of sierra nevadas version Ive had recently and it would annihilate this otherwise very fine example. STs example has a good classic highly carbonated medium mouthfeel, but it doesnt have the multiple layers of silkiness that sierra nevada has.
Hazy pale yellow-amber. Off-white foam. Fresh, citrusy, candy-ish aroma. Sticky feel. Good firm malt w/ lots of fresh hops.
Quite a hoppy zing in the aroma, golden amber, tiny head. Nice malt/hop taste, some orange here too. Well balanced, medium bodied, a pretty nice example.

UPDATED: JAN 25, 2005 Buffalo Brewfest 04.  This was my beer of the festival.  I thought this had a very unique "fresh" taste, even before the above description told me to think that.  Classic orange pour, strong floral hop aroma. Very strong fresh malt and hop taste.  The fruity hops are balanced well with the rest of the beer.  Fantastic, although my original review was infuenced by a day full of samples for sure.  I have since had this in a bottle and I still really enjoy it, it just isnt a 4.7 in my books, which I originally drunkenly rated it.  Nice beer though.
Tap.  Yellowish in color, moderate head.  Nice balance between malt and hops.  Aroma is malt with hop throughout.  Hops impart nice mild flavor.

With warm weather approaching (~75 today in Oxford) and leaving (highs in the 40s Saturday), the beer mood shifts from stouts, porters, and belgians to american pale ales and wheat beers.  This pale ale hits the spot.  Pours a clear amber orange with a thin off-white head.  Nice, classic APA aroma with grassy, earthy, floral hops.  These are abundant in the flavor as well, and the biscuity malt body provides just the right amount of balance.  There is a hint of lemon too.  Finishes with a piney bitterness.  A clean, solid APA that doesn't push too many boundaries but definitely satisfies.  Thanks Dan (jah noth)!

Head is initially average sized, frothy, off-white, mostly diminishing.
Body is hazy dark yellow. Aroma is moderately malty (cookie, bread),
moderately hoppy (herbs, grass, flowers, lemon). Flavor is moderately
sweet, lightly acidic, lightly bitter. Finish is lightly sweet,
moderately acidic, moderately bitter. Medium body, velvety texture,
lively carbonation, lightly astringent. Pretty nice brisk pale ale (kind
of an American/English hybrid).  Tartness is assertive in the finish but
brisk and fairly gentle compared to most APAs...again, I get the
impression this is a British ESB / American PA cross. I like the hop
aroma, it's strong but NOT the usual grapefruit/pine/resin attack...EKG
mixed with something else?  Interesting and enjoyable beer.

Copper hue with okay head and good lacing. The aroma hints of pine, grapefruit, lemon, toasted caramel malts, buttery biscuits, and hayfields. The taste is hoppy for sure, lots of pine and grapefruit. There is a solid malt base to balance this brew, nice. The bitterness lingers on and on. The mouthfeel is good and a bit chewy. A very good ale and worth seeking out.
Bottle. Nice orange color. Probably the hoppiest harvest ale I had tasted. A bit of pine and citrus as well. Very well done.

Pours a clear light amber, with a big fluffy white head that mostly lasts, leaved great lace on the glass.  Aroma is biscuity malts, with lots of fresh floral and pine from the abundant hops.  Flavor starts with some good biscuit and caramel maltiness, ends with a huge fresh tasting hoppy goodness.  Medium-full bodied, extremely good stuff.  Thanks to jah noth for this fine ale.

Pours a copper golden with a big frothy white head.  Freshly harvested hoppy aroma mixed with a light caramel malty sweetness.  Body has a nice dry sweetness and plenty of hops to support it.  A nice smooth hoppy, very drinkable beer.  Thanks frielock!
Orange, bright.  Whispy white head.  Aroma is lightish, but reveals chinooky, (or Centennial) notes (currany hops).  Toasty flavour.  Some sweet apricot notes.  hint of wood, currant.
Bright amber looking ale. Sweet , some honey malt with hops . Very smooth clean mouthfeel, malt nicely developed supported by fine hops bitterness.

Copper color, off white head. Very nice aroma of citrusy hops with some caramely malt in the background. Initially sweet up front with plenty of hop bitterness, nice balance between the two. Creamy texture. Very nice.

UPDATED: FEB 23, 2004 Pours a murky brown, but lighter towards the top, mahogany and chestnut reds.  Good beige head that lasts, lot of lacing, nice aroma of hops, lots of caramel malt and a good amount of alcohol.  Begins very malty, with lots of medium bitter hops background.  Texture is great, slightly carbonated, caramel malt lingers and turns into a butter toffee.  Finish is creamy and over fairly quick.  Not as good as some other harvests, but the balance is definitely there.  Flavor is true, just could use a bit more depth of hops profile.

My first rating, so excuse me if It is somewhat garbled.  The head pours nicely but dissipates rather quickly.  Aroma is sweet and hoppy.  Beautiful gold color with faint carbonation.  More of a Pale Ale than I was expedting, malt and hops are the main focus.

UPDATED: NOV 15, 2003 Clear golden orange color with a nice white head, great lacing down the glass. The tiny bubbles in the glass are truly amazing. Floral / citrusy hops in the nose. Sweet malts, flowers, citrus, and pine on the tongue. My favorite Pale Ale. Man, Southern Tier is making some of the best beers in Western NY. I'm glad this brewery is here
UPDATED: JAN 9, 2008 Hops and spice in the nose, golden body. medium white head. Citric hops well balanced with the malts.

Nice deep amber color, has a very spicy aroma.  Strong hops and malty flavoring.  This I would have to say is one of the better fall beers...almost gets you really wanting the next batch of winter beers, with all the wonderful spices.
UPDATED: NOV 5, 2003 Huge hoppy aroma. Clear golden brown body with a medium white head, nice lacing. Piney hop flavor with good malt balance.

UPDATED: JUN 22, 2004 Pours a transparent dark blonde/orange with a 1.5cm small bubbly white head. Aroma is spicy, maybe some cinnamon with a small yeastly hint.  This beer is very hoppy from start to finish.  There are mild notes of spice in there that make it somewhat interesting and the start is a little more mild. I mean, I dont see what makes this a harvest ale really.  Its more like an APA.----Re-rate---I had this again, and I must admit this is a very well-balanced beer that is very enjoyable.  I was sort of shocked when I first had this beer because it was so hoppy and I was expecting a maltier maarzen or something for a "harvest" ale.  Now that I'm past that shock, this is more decent than I remember.  I have decreased the aroma from a 7 to a 6, increased flavor from 5 to a 7, increased palate to a 4 from a 3 and increased overall to 14 from a 12.

UPDATED: OCT 30, 2003 Nice deep hue to beer.  Nice head.  Initially smells of fruits and hops.  First taste explodes in your mouth.  After two on tap I feel this is one of the best PAs made.  I got this on tap at McGregors in Rochester, NY

Copper colored with nive head and lace. Nose of sweet malt, full blown citric, piney hops. Medium bodied, hoppy as hell, sweet, toasted malt character, hops are everywhere, reminds me of a tamer version of bigfoot. Great brew.

Light amber in colour with a thin tan head. Very strong grapefruity hop aroma. Strong, fresh and very nice! Medium-bodied; Significant hoppy flavour with a good malt background. Aftertaste very bittered from the hops. Slight citrus taste from start-to-finish. Overall, a great IPA, well-balanced and complete! I wish this was a year-round offering, but it's great to have it very fresh. I had mine when it was less than a week old. I got this pint on draught at MacGregor's in Rochester, New York.
